revision.text:
'''Cytochrome P450 omega hydroxylases''', also termed '''cytochrome P450 ω-hydroxylases''', '''CYP450 omega hydroxylases''', '''CYP450 ω-hydroxylases''', '''CYP omega hydroxylase''', '''CYP ω-hydroxylases''', '''fatty acid omega hydroxylases''', '''cytochrome P450 monooxygenases''', and '''fatty acid monooxygenases''', are a set of [[cytochrome P450]]-containing enzymes that catalyze the addition of a [[hydroxyl]] residue to a [[fatty acid]] [[Substrate (chemistry)]]. The CYP omega hydroxylases are often referred to as monoxygenases; however, the [[monooxygenase]]s are CYP450 enzymes that add a hydroxyl group to a wide range of [[xenobiotic]] (e.g. drugs, industrial toxins) and naturally occurring endobiotic (e.g. cholesterol) substrates, most of which are not fatty acids. The CYP450 omega hydroxylases are accordingly better viewed as a subset of monooxygenases that have the ability to hydroxylate fatty acids. While once regarded as functioning mainly in the [[catabolism]] of dietary fatty acids, the omega oxygenases are now considered critical in the production or break-down of fatty acid-derived mediators which are made by cells and act within their cells of origin as [[autocrine signaling]] agents or on nearby cells as [[paracrine signaling]] agents to regulate various functions such as blood pressure control and inflammation.
==Action== The omega oxygenases metabolize fatty acids (RH) by adding a hydroxyl (OH) to their terminal (i.e. furthest from the fatty acids' carboxy residue) carbons; in the reaction, the two atoms of molecular oxygen(O<sub>2</sub>[ are reduced to one hydroxyl group and one water (H<sub>2</sub>O molecule) by the concomitant oxidation of [[NAD(P)H]] (see [[monooxygenase]]).<ref name="PUB00000123">{{cite journal |vauthors=Harayama S, Kok M, Neidle EL |title=Functional and evolutionary relationships among diverse oxygenases |journal=Annu. Rev. Microbiol. |volume=46 |issue= |pages=565–601 |year=1992 |pmid=1444267 |doi=10.1146/annurev.mi.46.100192.003025}}</ref><ref name="PUB00006431">{{cite journal |vauthors=Schreuder HA, van Berkel WJ, Eppink MH, Bunthol C |title=Phe161 and Arg166 variants of p-hydroxybenzoate hydroxylase. Implications for NADPH recognition and structural stability |journal=FEBS Lett. |volume=443 |issue=3 |pages=251–255 |year=1999 |pmid=10025942 |doi=10.1016/S0014-5793(98)01726-8}}</ref>
<center> RH + O<sub>2</sub> + NADPH + H<sup>+</sup> → ROH + H<sub>2</sub>O + NADP<sup>+</sup> </center>
==Functions== CYP450 enzymes belong to a superfamily which in humans is composed of at least 57 CYPs; within this superfamily, members of six CYP4A subfamilies, (which are CYP4A, CYP4B, CYP4F, CYP4V, CYP4X, and CYP4z) possess ω-hydroxylase activity viz., CYP4A, CYP4B, and CYP4F<ref name="Panigrahy_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Panigrahy D, Kaipainen A, Greene ER, Huang S | title = Cytochrome P450-derived eicosanoids: the neglected pathway in cancer | journal = Cancer Metastasis Reviews | volume = 29 | issue = 4 | pages = 723–35 | date = Dec 2010 | pmid = 20941528 | pmc = 2962793 | doi = 10.1007/s10555-010-9264-x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15822183 | year = 2005 | author1 = Kroetz | first1 = D. L. | title = Regulation and inhibition of arachidonic acid omega-hydroxylases and 20-HETE formation | journal = Annual Review of Pharmacology and Toxicology | volume = 45 | pages = 413–38 | last2 = Xu | first2 = F | doi = 10.1146/annurev.pharmtox.45.120403.100045 }}</ref> [[CYP2U1]] also possesses ω hydroxylase activity.<ref name="pmid14660610">{{cite journal | pmid = 14660610 | year = 2004 | author1 = Chuang | first1 = S. S. | title = CYP2U1, a novel human thymus- and brain-specific cytochrome P450, catalyzes omega- and (omega-1)-hydroxylation of fatty acids | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 8 | pages = 6305–14 | last2 = Helvig | first2 = C | last3 = Taimi | first3 = M | last4 = Ramshaw | first4 = H. A. | last5 = Collop | first5 = A. H. | last6 = Amad | first6 = M | last7 = White | first7 = J. A. | last8 = Petkovich | first8 = M | last9 = Jones | first9 = G | last10 = Korczak | first10 = B | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M311830200 }}</ref> These CYP ω-hydroxylases can be categorized into several groups based on their substrates and consequential function
*1) The only member of the CYP4B subfamily, [[CYP4B1]], shows a preference for ω-oxidizing [[short-chain fatty acid]]s, i.e. fatty acids that are 7-9 carbons long; CYP4B1 is far more weakly expressed in humans than that expressed in other mammals that were tested.<ref name="pmid26233909">{{cite journal | pmid = 26233909 | pmc = 4667791 | year = 2015 | author1 = Johnson | first1 = A. L. | title = Cytochrome P450 Function and Pharmacological Roles in Inflammation and Cancer | journal = Advances in pharmacology (San Diego, Calif.) | volume = 74 | pages = 223–62 | last2 = Edson | first2 = K. Z. | last3 = Totah | first3 = R. A. | last4 = Rettie | first4 = A. E. | doi = 10.1016/bs.apha.2015.05.002| series = Advances in Pharmacology | isbn = 9780128031193 }}</ref> Subsequent to their ω-hydroxylation, these products are converted to their acyl[[carnitine]] derivatives and transferred to [[mitochondria]] for complete oxidized by [[beta oxidation]] (see also [[omega oxidation]]).<ref name="pmid18433732">{{cite journal | pmid = 18433732 | year = 2008 | author1 = Hardwick | first1 = J. P. | title = Cytochrome P450 omega hydroxylase (CYP4) function in fatty acid metabolism and metabolic diseases | journal = Biochemical Pharmacology | volume = 75 | issue = 12 | pages = 2263–75 | doi = 10.1016/j.bcp.2008.03.004 }}</ref> *2) A member of the CYP4A subfamily, [[CYP4A11]], preferentially ω-hydroxylate [[medium-chain fatty acids]], i.e. fatty acids that are 10-16 carbons long; [[CYP4A11]], [[CYP4F2]], [[CYP4F3]]A, [[CYP4F3]]B, [[CYP4F11]], [[CYP4V2]], and [[CYP4Z1]] also metabolize these fatty acids.<ref name="pmid26233909"/> Subsequent to their ω-hydroxylation, these products are converted to their acyl[[carnitine]] derivatives and transferred to [[mitochondria]] for complete oxidized by [[beta oxidation]] (see also [[omega oxidation]]).<ref name="pmid18433732"/> *3) Members of the CYP4F family, i.e. CYPA11, CYP4F2, CYP4F3A, CYP4F3B, and CYP4F11, as well as CYP2U1 ω-hydroxylate long chain fatty acids, i.e. fatty acids that are 18 to 20 carbons long.<ref name="pmid18433732"/> These hydroxyl fatty acids are then serially metabolized by [[alcohol dehydrogenase]], [[aldehyde dehydrogenase]], and dicarboxylyl CoA synthetase to form their respective [[Coenzyme A]] (CoA)-bound dicarboxylic acids and transferred to [[peroxisome]]s where they may undergo chain shortening or, as acylcarnitine derivatives or free acids, transferred to mitochondria for complete beta oxidation. The chain-shortened products of peroxisome metabolism may also be converted to [[phospholipid]]s, [[triglycerides]], and [[cholesterol ester]]s.<ref name="pmid18433732"/> *4) Members of the CYP4F family, i.e. CYP4F2 and CYP4F3B, ω-hydroxylate [[very long chain fatty acids]], i.e. fatty acids that are 22 to 26 carbons long.<ref name="pmid18433732"/> These hydroxyl fatty acids are then serially metabolized by [[alcohol dehydrogenase]], [[aldehyde dehydrogenase]], and dicarboxylyl CoA synthetase to form their respective CoA-bound dicarboxylic acids and transferred to [[peroxisome]]s where they may undergo chain shortening or, as acylcarnitine derivatives or free acids, transferred to mitochondria for complete beta oxidation. The chain-shortened products of peroxisome metabolism may also be converted to [[phospholipid]]s, [[triglycerides]], and [[cholesterol ester]]s.<ref name="pmid18433732"/> *5) [[CYP4F22]] ω-hydroxylates extremely long very long chain fatty acids, i.e. fatty acids that are 28 or more carbons long. The ω-hydroxylation of these special fatty acids is critical to creating and maintaining the skins water barrier function; autosomal recessive inactivating mutations of CYP4F22 are associated with the [[Lamellar ichthyosis]] subtype of [[Congenital ichthyosiform erythrodema]] in humans.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25982146 | year = 2015 | author1 = Sugiura | first1 = K | title = Update on autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis: MRNA analysis using hair samples is a powerful tool for genetic diagnosis | journal = Journal of Dermatological Science | volume = 79 | issue = 1 | pages = 4–9 | last2 = Akiyama | first2 = M | doi = 10.1016/j.jdermsci.2015.04.009 }}</ref> *6) CYP4F2, CYP4F3A, CYP4F3B, and CYP4F11 ω-hydroxylate [[leukotriene B4]] and very probably [[5-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid]] and [[5-oxo-eicosatetraenoic acid]].<ref name="pmid26233909"/> This hydroxylation greatly reduces the ability of these arachidonic acid metabolites to stimulate cells that mediate [[inflammation]] and [[allergic reactions]] and may thereby limit and contribute to the resolution of these [[innate immunity]] reactions.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 3095426 | year = 1986 | author1 = O'Flaherty | first1 = J. T. | title = Metabolism of 5-hydroxyicosatetraenoate by human neutrophils: Production of a novel omega-oxidized derivative | journal = Journal of Immunology | volume = 137 | issue = 10 | pages = 3277–83 | last2 = Wykle | first2 = R. L. | last3 = Redman | first3 = J | last4 = Samuel | first4 = M | last5 = Thomas | first5 = M }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25449650 | year = 2015 | author1 = Powell | first1 = W. S. | title = Biosynthesis, biological effects, and receptors of hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids (HETEs) and oxoeicosatetraenoic acids (oxo-ETEs) derived from arachidonic acid | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids | volume = 1851 | issue = 4 | pages = 340–55 | last2 = Rokach | first2 = J | doi = 10.1016/j.bbalip.2014.10.008 }}</ref> One or more of these CYPs also omega hydroxylate [[12-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid]], [[lipoxin]]s, [[hepoxilin]]s, and acyl[[ceramides]]<ref name="pmid26233909"/> and may thereby contribute to limiting there biological effects. (However, the 20-hydroxy metabolite of 12-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid proved able to contract coronary arteries.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 8652640 | year = 1996 | author1 = Rosolowsky | first1 = M | title = Metabolism of arachidonic acid by canine polymorphonuclear leukocytes synthesis of lipoxygenase and omega-oxidized metabolites | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1300 | issue = 2 | pages = 143–50 | last2 = Falck | first2 = J. R. | last3 = Campbell | first3 = W. B. | doi=10.1016/0005-2760(95)00238-3}}</ref>) *7) CYP4A11, CYP4F2, CYP4F3B, CYP4F11, CYP4F12, CYP4V2, CYP2U1, and possibly CYP4Z1 metabolize arachidonic acid to [[20-Hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid]] (20-HETE).<ref name="pmid26233909"/><ref name="pmid14660610"/> Animal and human tissue studies suggest that the CYP-dependent production of 20-HETE contributes to the regulation of blood pressure, the growth of certain cancers, and the [[metabolic syndrome]] while genetic studies on [[single nucleotide polymorphism]] in humans support roles for: '''a)''' CYP4F11-dependent 20-HETE production in the prevention of hypertension; '''b)''' CYP4F2-dependent 20-HETE production of 20-HETE in the prevention of hypertension, [[ischemic stroke]], and [[myocardial infarction]]; and '''c)''' CYP2U1 in [[Hereditary spastic paraplegia]], possibly by a 20-HETE-dependent mechanism in a small percentage of patients with this disease (see [[20-Hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid#Human studies]]). Some or possibly even all of these CYPs may also omega hydroxylate [[eicosapentaenoic acid]] (EPA) and [[docosahexaenoic acid]] (DHA). 20-hydroxy EPA and 20-hydroxy-DHA do stimulate [[Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha]] but their range of biological activities have yet to be investigated.<ref name="pmid26233909"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Cell biology]] [[Category:Metabolic pathways]] [[Category:Fatty acids]] [[Category:EC 1.14]] [[Category:Cytochrome P450|*]] [[Category:Integral membrane proteins]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Sexuality and religion]]; added [[Category:Sexual abstinence and religion]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[File:Guillaume Seignac - Diana the Huntress.jpg|thumb|right|19th-century painting of the Roman goddess Diana by [[Guillaume Seignac]]]] '''Dianism''' is a 19th-century American spiritual sexual practice consisting of "sexual satisfaction from sexual contact" but without ejaculation.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2jxZBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT292|title=Book of Lies: The Disinformation Guide to Magick and the Occult|first=Metzger|last=Richard|date=1 September 2014|publisher=Disinformation Books|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> The practice was named for Diana, the Roman goddess of chastity, by American court reporter and astronomer [[Henry M. Parkhurst]] in his 1882 pamphlet ''Diana''.<ref name="auto4">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0LwMwuU1vxMC&pg=PA148|title=Sex Radicals and the Quest for Women's Equality|first=Joanne Ellen|last=Passet|date=7 August 2017|publisher=University of Illinois Press|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books|page=148}}</ref> In the 1890s, sexual mystic [[Ida Craddock]] included Dianism as part of her teachings.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoybRLX4jqIC&pg=PA24|title=Sexual Outlaw, Erotic Mystic: The Essential Ida Craddock|first=Vere|last=Chappell|date=1 December 2010|publisher=Weiser Books|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books|page=24}}</ref> In the 20th century, the practice found favor with American followers of [[Aleister Crowley]], most notably [[C.F. Russell]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TzMOAQAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Dianism|title=Encyclopedia of American Religions|first=J. Gordon|last=Melton|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Gale|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books|page=176}}</ref>
==Henry M. Parkhurst== [[Henry M. Parkhurst]] (March 1, 1825 - January 21, 1908) was an American stenographer who served as Chief Official Court Reporter for the US Senate, an astronomer with pioneering work in [[Photometry (astronomy)|Photometry]], and an author.<ref name="harvard.edu">{{cite journal|url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1908PA.....16..231P|title=Henry M. Parkhurst|author=J.A. Parkhurst|bibcode=1908PA.....16..231P|journal=Popular Astronomy|volume=16|page=231|via=adsabs.harvard.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abebooks.com/book-search/author/parkhurst-henry-martyn-1825-1908/|title=Parkhurst Henry Martyn 1825 1908 - AbeBooks|website=www.abebooks.com}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoybRLX4jqIC&pg=PR23|title=Sexual Outlaw, Erotic Mystic: The Essential Ida Craddock|first=Vere|last=Chappell|date=1 December 2010|publisher=Weiser Books|via=Google Books}}</ref>
In 1882, Henry M. Parkhurst anonymously published ''"Diana: A psycho-fyziological essay on sexual relations, for married men and women"''.<ref name="auto4"/> <ref name="auto1">{{cite book|author=Leigh Eric Schmidt|title=Village Atheists: How America's Unbelievers Made Their Way in a Godly Nation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3rbYDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA316|date=26 September 2016|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-1-4008-8434-6|page=316}}</ref><ref name="Brumberg2000">{{cite book|author=Joan Jacobs Brumberg|title=Fasting Girls: The History of Anorexia Nervosa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2CTBv82tKt8C&pg=RA1-PA3|year=2000|publisher=Vintage Books|isbn=978-0-375-72448-0|page=303}}</ref><ref name="auto2">{{cite book|first=Joanne Ellen |last=Passet|title=Sex Radicals and the Quest for Women's Equality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0LwMwuU1vxMC&pg=PA148|year=2003|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-02804-5|page=148}}</ref> The pamphlet was promoted by fellow stenographer [[Eliza Boardman Burnz]], who authored a "Letter to parents and instructors" included in the pamphlet.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gs09AAAAYAAJ&pg=PT3|title=Burnz' Phonic Shorthand for Schools, Business Writing and Reporting: Arranged on the Basis of Isaac Pitman's "Phonography"|first=Eliza Boardman|last=Burnz|date=7 August 1883|publisher=Burnz & Company|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7FMEAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA439|title=Works|first=graf Leo|last=Tolstoy|date=7 August 1886|publisher=Colonial Press|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> Later editions also included a review by [[Leo Tolstoy]].<ref>http://www.iapsop.com/ssoc/1895__parkhurst___diana_a_psycho_fyziological_essay_on_sexual_relations____6ed.pdf</ref> The pamphlet was written in "reform spelling".<ref name="auto3">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoybRLX4jqIC&pg=PA130|title=Sexual Outlaw, Erotic Mystic: The Essential Ida Craddock|first=Vere|last=Chappell|date=1 December 2010|publisher=Weiser Books|via=Google Books|page=130}}</ref> Parkhurst named his practice after the goddess of chastity.<ref name="auto2"/>
While Parkhurst drew inspiration from radical religious philosopher [[John Humphrey Noyes]],<ref name="auto2"/> Dianism is "radically different" from Noyes's "male continence" or [[Alice Bunker Stockham|Stockham's]] "karezza".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zYM-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA212|title=Sex Secrets|first=Robert B.|last=Armitage|date=7 August 2017|publisher=Advanced Thought Publishing Company|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xG5VCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT140|title=The Sex Side of Life: You are the Society|first=Mary Ware|last=Dennett|date=7 January 2016|publisher=谷月社|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>
Parkhurt later took credit for the pamphlet, authoring the 1887 work "Why I Wrote 'Diana'".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3rbYDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA316|title=Village Atheists: How America's Unbelievers Made Their Way in a Godly Nation|first=Leigh Eric|last=Schmidt|date=26 September 2016|publisher=Princeton University Press|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>
==Elmina Slenker== [[File:Lucifer, The Light-Bearer.jpg|thumb|left|From 1895 to 1900, Slenker published at least six articles on Dianism in the anarchist journal [[Lucifer the Lightbearer]].]] [[File:Elmina D. Slenker.jpg|thumb|19th-century American Freethought leader and early sex reformer Elmina Drake Slenker was a regular contributor to [[Lucifer the Lightbearer]] and an early promoter of Dianism.]] [[Elmina Slenker]] was a "prominent promoter of the 'Diana method' of continence and distributor of the pamphlet Diana which explained to readers how to practice sexual expression without fears of conception".<ref>https://mospace.umsystem.edu/xmlui/bitstream/handle/10355/40123/research.pdf?sequence=2</ref><ref name="auto5">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gsddNlV-rGwC&pg=PA46|title=Evolutionary Rhetoric: Sex, Science, and Free Love in Nineteenth-Century Feminism|first=Wendy|last=Hayden|date=14 February 2013|publisher=SIU Press|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>
Slenker described herself as Dianist free lover" and advised her readers to "conserve the life forces and not needlessly waste them in mere 'paroxysms of pleasure'.<ref name="auto5"/><ref name="auto4"/><ref name="auto2b">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gsddNlV-rGwC&pg=PA46|title=Evolutionary Rhetoric: Sex, Science, and Free Love in Nineteenth-Century Feminism|first=Wendy|last=Hayden|date=14 February 2013|publisher=SIU Press|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="auto4b">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ELIJD2ErMgwC&pg=PA260|title=Women and Health in America: Historical Readings|first=Judith Walzer|last=Leavitt|date=13 August 1999|publisher=Univ of Wisconsin Press|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="auto5c">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cq3FkAiZ23UC&pg=PA60&lpg=PA60|title=Dreamers of a New Day: Women Who Invented the Twentieth Century|first=Sheila|last=Rowbotham|date=1 July 2011|publisher=Verso Books|via=Google Books}}</ref>
In April 1887, Slenker was arrested under the [[Comstock Act]] for sending sex-advice through the mail.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fsZ26vQxJKMC&pg=PA718|title=The New Encyclopedia of Unbelief|first=Richard|last=Dawkins|date=7 August 2017|publisher=Prometheus Books|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> On November 4, 1887, Slenker was freed by a judge.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ffrf.org/component/k2/item/14720-elmina-d-slenker|title=Elmina D. Slenker - Freedom From Religion Foundation|website=ffrf.org|accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref> Parkhurst briefly took the stand in her defense at her trial.<ref name="auto1"/><ref name="auto5"/> {{clear-right}}
==Ida Craddock== [[File:IdaCraddock.jpg|thumb|right|Occultist and sex reformer [[Ida Craddock]]]] Ida Craddock (August 1, 1857 – October 16, 1902) was a 19th-century American occultist, Theosophist, and author, sex reformer and mystic.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Chappell | first = Vere | title = Ida Craddock: Sexual Mystic and Martyr for Freedom | accessdate = 2009-08-10 | url = http://www.idacraddock.org/}}</ref>
Craddock developed an interest in the [[occult]] through her association with the [[Theosophical Society]] beginning around 1887. She tried in her writings to synthesize translated mystic literature and traditions from many cultures into a scholarly, distilled whole. Craddock became a student of religious eroticism and declared herself a Priestess and Pastor of the Church of Yoga. Never married, Craddock eventually claimed to have a blissful ongoing marital relationship with an [[angel]] named Soph. Craddock even stated that her intercourse with Soph was so noisy as to draw complaints from her neighbors.<ref name=Schaechterle>{{Cite journal | publisher = OhioLINK; Bowling Green State University | last = Schaechterle | first = Inez L | title = Speaking of Sex: The Rhetorical Strategies of Frances Willard, Victoria Woodhull, and Ida Craddock | accessdate = 2009-08-10 | year = 2005 | url = http://rave.ohiolink.edu/etdc/view?acc_num}}</ref> Her mother responded by threatening to burn Craddock's papers and unsuccessfully tried to have her institutionalized.
In Chicago, Craddock opened an office offering "mystical" sexual counseling to married couples via both walk-in counseling and mail order. She dedicated herself to “preventing sexual evils and sufferings” by educating adults.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Burton | first = Shirley J | title = Women Making a Difference: Ida Craddock, Adelaide Johnson, and Laura Dainty Pelham | accessdate = 2009-08-10 | url = http://www.lib.niu.edu/1997/iht419722.html}}</ref><ref>Burton, Shirley J. "[http://www.sil.si.edu/silpublications/Worlds-Fairs/WF_selected.cfm?categories=World%27s%20Columbian%20Exhibition%2C%20Chicago%201893 Obscene, Lewd, and Lascivious: Ida Craddock and the Criminally Obscene Women of Chicago, 1873-1913]." Michigan Historical Review 19: 1 (1993): 1-16.</ref>
In 1894, Craddock authored "Heavenly Bridegrooms", in which she described her sexual relationship with a spiritual being she called Soph.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idacraddock.com/bridegrooms.html|title=Heavenly Bridegrooms|website=www.idacraddock.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref> In 1899, she authored "Psychic Wedlock", which provided further detail on her spiritual worldview and recommended training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idacraddock.com/psychic.html|title=Psychic Wedlock|website=www.idacraddock.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref>
===Craddock's three planes=== Craddock cites [[New Thought]] leader Alma Gillen, a London teacher of "Divine Healing" (also called "Divine Science"), who divides the universe into three 'factors': (1) The Thinker (that which thinks); (2) The mentality, "where thoughts are shaped"; and (3) "the body, the material life, where spirit finds expression as outward form."<ref name="idacraddock.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.idacraddock.com/bridegrooms.html|title=Heavenly Bridegrooms|author=|date=|website=www.idacraddock.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jt51TBulIhwC&pg=PA119|title=Heaven's Bride: The Unprintable Life of Ida C. Craddock, American Mystic, Scholar, Sexologist, Martyr, and Madwoman|first=Leigh Eric|last=Schmidt|date=7 December 2010|publisher=Basic Books|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> Craddock explains that "it is incorrect to say 'I *have* spirit.' We should say 'I *am* a spirit'".<ref name="idacraddock.com"/>
Craddock argues that "every act ... consists of three stages." which she illustrates by stating: "Let us suppose a man: :1. conceives the idea of pushing a ball out of his path; :2. he determines how the ball shall be pushed aside, with hand or foot, gently or powerfully, etc.; :3. at the command of his mentality, his body performs the act of moving the ball."<ref name="idacraddock.com1">{{cite web|url=http://www.idacraddock.com/psychic.html|title=Psychic Wedlock|author=|date=|website=www.idacraddock.com}}</ref>
===Craddock's three degrees of training=== Craddock refers to the first degree, known as "Alpha-ism", which she defines as "No sex union except for the distinct purpose of begetting a child". Craddock emphasized the importance of Alpha-ism during pregnancy, claiming that "Modern researchers have shown the impressionability of the embryo child during gestation" and that "Napoleon the Great owed his remarkable military genius to the fact that, prior to his birth, his mother accompanied her husband through a military campaign."<ref name="idacraddock.com1"/>
After mastering Alpha-ism, Craddock's suggests readers consult Parkhurt's pamphlet "Diana" as an introduction to the second degree, which is "the most difficult of the three degrees to acquire, physiologically speaking, inasmuch as it exacts supreme self-control at a crucial moment."<ref name="idacraddock.com"/> But Craddock promises that "as the power of self-control is developed, it becomes and more possible for a man to do here just what he wills. And no man who has once acquired this power will ever care to return to the old habit of abandonment to passion; for he will see that he was then a slave, whereas now he is a king".<ref name="idacraddock.com1"/>
Craddock writes that: "There is a belief among some occultists that an earnest wish breathed at that time, when husband and wife are one, will not fail to be granted. This opens, it is said, the door to those who practice what is called 'black magic', and enables them to work harm upon other human beings." Craddock continues: "What foundation there is for this belief as applied to the magicians I do not see. If it really be that a wish is granted then more readily than when the seeker is in any other mood, it is probably because the occultist who attains the second degree has to exercise such supreme self-control at that moment that he is complete master of his sub-consciousness".<ref name="idacraddock.com"/>
According to Craddock the "Third and Highest Degree", involves "Communion with Deity as the third partner in marital union".<ref name="idacraddock.com1"/>
==Crowleyites== [[File:Aleister Crowley, Magus.png|thumb|right|Occultist Aleister Crowley in 1912]] In 1915, American author [[Theodore Schroeder]] published Ida Craddock's ''Heavenly Bridegrooms'', along with a brief introduction, in the pages of the journal ''The Alienist and Neurologist''.<ref name="auto6">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KpvqhORGQe4C&pg=PT178|title=Aleister Crowley and Western Esotericism|first1=Henrik|last1=Bogdan|first2=Martin P.|last2=Starr|date=5 September 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HlEvfflQZbIC&pg=PA282|title=Perdurabo: The Life of Aleister Crowley|first=Richard|last=Kaczynski|date=7 August 2017|publisher=North Atlantic Books|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> Schroeder was an associate of occultist Aleister Crowley, and introduced Craddock's work to Crowley.<Ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoybRLX4jqIC&pg=PA245|title=Sexual Outlaw, Erotic Mystic: The Essential Ida Craddock|first=Vere|last=Chappell|date=1 December 2010|publisher=Weiser Books|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> In 1919, Crowley reviewed ''Heavenly Bridegrooms'' in the pages of the journal ''[[The Equinox]]'', stating that it was:
{{Quote |...one of the most remarkable human documents ever produced, and it should certainly find a regular publisher in book form. The authoress of the MS. claims that she was the wife of an angel. She expounds at the greatest length the philosophy connected with this thesis. Her learning is enormous.
...This book is of incalculable value to every student of occult matters. No Magick library is complete without it.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Universal | volume = III | editor-first = Aleister | editor-last= Crowley | title = [[The Blue Equinox]] | location = Detroit, MI | year = 1919}}</ref>}}
Schroeder was subsequently contacted by notable Crowley followers included British Columbia OTO founder [[Charles Stansfeld Jones]] and Crowley's New York based representative [[Karl Germer]].<ref name="auto6"/>
In 1932, Crowley-associate American [[C.F. Russell]] founded his own occult group, the GBG.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MmAoDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT63|title=The Great Work of the Flesh: Sexual Magic East and West|first=Sarane|last=Alexandrian|date=30 January 2015|publisher=Simon and Schuster|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> Russell developed his own curriculum of [[sex magick]].<ref name="CullingWeschcke2010">{{cite book|author1=Louis T. Culling|author2=Carl Llewellyn Weschcke|title=The Complete Magick Curriculum of the Secret Order G.B.G.: Being the Entire Study, Curriculum, Magick Rituals, and Initiatory Practices of the G.B.G (The Great Brotherhood of God)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yFs3qoTFVz8C&pg=PA12|date=8 September 2010|publisher=Llewellyn Worldwide|isbn=978-0-7387-2674-8|page=12|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> GBG disciple Louis T. Culling later published these in two works entitled ''The Complete Magickal Curriculum of the Secret Order G.'.B.'.G.'.'' and ''Sex Magick''.<ref>{{Cite book|isbn=0-7387-1912-9|title=The Complete Magick Curriculum of the Secret Order G.B.G.: Being the Entire Study, Curriculum, Magick Rituals, and Initiatory Practices of the G.B.G (The Great Brotherhood of God)|author= Louis T. Culling|author2= Carl Llewellyn Weschcke|publisher=}}</ref> The first two degrees are "Alphaism and Dianism".<ref name="Chappell2010">{{cite book|author=Vere Chappell|title=Sexual Outlaw, Erotic Mystic: The Essential Ida Craddock|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoybRLX4jqIC&pg=PA244|date=1 December 2010|publisher=Weiser Books|isbn=978-1-60925-296-0|page=244}}</ref><ref name="CullingWeschcke2010"/> Culling writes that Dianism is "sexual congress without bringing it to climax" and that each participant is to regard their partner not as a "known earthly personality" but as a "visible manifestation of one's [[Holy Guardian Angel]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yFs3qoTFVz8C&pg=PA127|title=The Complete Magick Curriculum of the Secret Order G.B.G.: Being the Entire Study, Curriculum, Magick Rituals, and Initiatory Practices of the G.B.G (The Great Brotherhood of God)|last=Culling|first=Louis T.|last2=Weschcke|first2=Carl Llewellyn|date=|publisher=Llewellyn Worldwide|year=2010|isbn=9780738726748|location=|page=127|language=en|oclc=793421982|chapter=Sex Magick}}</ref> After his involvement with the GBG, in 1938, Culling joined the [[Agape Lodge]], the Southern California chapter of the OTO.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zOJoAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA365|title=Aleister Crowley and Western Esotericism|first1=Henrik|last1=Bogdan|first2=Martin P.|last2=Starr|date=1 August 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LxCwyChmJrAC&pg=PA198|title=Satanism Today|first=James R.|last=Lewis|date=7 August 2017|publisher=ABC-CLIO|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> Dianism was also promoted by 1960s and 70s spiritual leader [[Father Yod]] as part of his New Age organization called "The Source Family".<ref>[[The Source Family]] (2012 documentary)</ref>
In 1981, [[Marcelo Ramos Motta]], a student of Karl Germer who went on to become leader the OTO in Brazil, re-published Heavenly Bridegrooms and Psychic Wedlock.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KpvqhORGQe4C&pg=PT178|title=Aleister Crowley and Western Esotericism|first1=Henrik|last1=Bogdan|first2=Martin P.|last2=Starr|date=5 September 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=7 August 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>

This article contains list of '''discrete dipole approximation codes''' and their applications.
The [[discrete dipole approximation]] (DDA) is a flexible technique for computing scattering and absorption by targets of arbitrary geometry. Given a target of arbitrary geometry, one seeks to calculate its scattering and absorption properties. The DDA is an approximation of the continuum target by a finite array of polarizable points. The points acquire dipole moments in response to the local electric field. The dipoles of course interact with one another via their electric fields, so the DDA is also sometimes referred to as the coupled dipole approximation. It is closely related to method of moments, digitized Green's function, or volume integral equation method.
==Classification== The compilation contains information about the [[discrete dipole approximation]], relevant links, and their applications. [[Image:Trees showing the presence of creep.jpg|thumb|Trees showing the effect of creep.{{fact|date=April 2016}}]] '''Downhill creep''', also known as '''soil creep''' or commonly just '''creep''', is the slow [[Mass wasting|downward progression]] of [[rock (geology)|rock]] and [[soil]] down a low [[Grade (slope)|grade]] slope; it can also refer to slow deformation of such materials as a result of prolonged pressure and stress. Creep may appear to an observer to be continuous, but it really is the sum of numerous minute, discrete movements of slope material caused by the force of [[gravity]]. Friction, being the primary force to resist gravity, is produced when one body of material slides past another offering a mechanical resistance between the two which acts to hold objects (or slopes) in place. As slope on a hill increases, the gravitational force that is perpendicular to the slope decreases and results in less friction between the material that could cause the slope to slide.
==Overview== {{unreferenced section|date = August 2013}} The rate of soil creep down a slope depends on the steepness (gradient) of the slope, water absorption and content, type of sediment and material, and lastly vegetation. The rate of creep will take into account all of these factors to decide whether or not the hillside will progress downward. Creep is what is responsible for the rounded shape of hillsides. [[File:Victorian_headstones,_England.JPG|right|thumb|A group of Victorian [[headstone]]s, [[England]]. Soil creep has led to the headstones being tilted at an angle over time.]] Water is a very important factor when discussing soil deformation and movement. For instance, a sandcastle will only stand up when it is made with damp sand. The water offers cohesion to the sand which binds the sand particles together. However, pouring water over the sandcastle destroys it. This is because the presence of too much water fills the pores between the grains with water creating a slip plane between the particles and offering no cohesion causing them to slip and slide away. This holds true for hillsides and creep as well. The presence of water may help the hillside stay put and give it cohesion, but in a very wet environment or during or after a large amount of precipitation the pores between the grains can become saturated with water and cause the ground to slide along the slip plane it creates.
[[Image:Hillside moving over a sidewalk.jpg|thumb|Creep has caused the soil to spread over this pavement.]] Creep can also be caused by the expansion of materials such as [[clay]] when they are exposed to water. Clay expands when wet, then contracts after drying. The expansion portion pushes downhill, then the contraction results in consolidation at the new offset.
Objects resting on top of the soil are carried by it as it descends down the slope. This can be seen in churchyards, where older [[headstones]] are often situated at an angle and several metres away from where they were originally erected.
Vegetation plays a role with slope stability and creep. When a hillside contains many trees, ferns, and shrubs their roots create an interlocking network that can strengthen unconsolidated material. They also aid in absorbing the excess water in the soil to help keep the slope stable. However, they do add to the weight of the slope giving gravity that much more of a driving force to act on in pushing the slope downward. In general, though, slopes without vegetation have a greater chance of movement.
Design engineers sometimes need to guard against downhill creep during their planning to prevent building [[foundation (architecture)|foundations]] from being undermined. Pilings are planted sufficiently deep into the surface material to guard against this behavior.
==Modeling regolith diffusion== For shallow to moderate slopes, diffusional sediment flux is modeled linearly as (Culling, 1960; McKean et al., 1993)
<math>q_s = k_d S \,\!</math>
where <math>k_d\,\!</math> is the diffusion constant, and <math>S\,\!</math> is slope. For steep slopes, diffusional sediment flux is more appropriately modeled as a non-linear function of slope<ref name="Roering1999" />
<math>q_s = \frac{k_d S}{1 - (S/S_c)^2}\,\!</math>
where <math>S_c\,\!</math> is the critical gradient for sliding of dry soil.
On long timescales, diffusive creep in hillslope soils leads to a characteristic rounding of ridges in the landscape.<ref name="Roering1999">Roering, Joshua J., James W. Kirchner, and William E. Dietrich. "Evidence for nonlinear, diffusive sediment transport on hillslopes and implications for landscape morphology." Water Resources Research 35.3 (1999): 853–70.</ref><ref>Rosenbloom, N. A., and Robert S. Anderson. "Hillslope and channel evolution in a marine terraced landscape, Santa Cruz." California: Journal of Geophysical Research 99.B7 (1994): 14-013.</ref>
{{Wide image|Hillslopes near Lebec, CA.JPG|700px|Convex hillslopes near Lebec, southern California, USA. Creep in the underlying soils has produced the rounded form of the hilltops.{{fact|date=April 2016}}}}
==See also== * [[Colluvium]] * [[Mass wasting]] * [[Gravitational erosion]] * [[Sediment transport]] * [[Solifluction]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== {{Commons category|Soil creep}} * Culling, 1960. * McKean et al., 1993. * Monkhouse, F. J. (University of Southampton). ''A Dictionary of Geography''. London: Edward Arnold (Publishers) Ltd. 1978. * Roering, Kirchner and Dietrich, 1999. Evidence for nonlinear diffusive sediment transport on hilslopes and implications for landscape morphology. ''Water Resour. Res.'', 35:853–87. * Strahler, Arthur N. ''Physical Geography''. New York: John Wiley & Sons, 1960, 2nd edition, 7th printing, pp. 318–19 * Easterbrook, Don J., 1999, ''Surface Processes and Landforms'', Prentice-Hall, Inc.
[[Category:Environmental soil science]] [[Category:Geomorphology]] [[Category:Soil erosion]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Waterflow|the town in the United States|Waterflow, New Mexico}} '''Environmental flows''' describe the quantity, timing, and quality of '''water flows''' required to sustain [[freshwater ecosystem|freshwater]] and [[estuarine]] [[ecosystem]]s and the human livelihoods and well being that depend on these ecosystems. In the [[India]]n context [[river]] flows required for [[Culture|cultural]] and [[Spirituality|spiritual]] needs assumes significance.<ref>http://awsassets.wwfindia.org/downloads/exec_summary_mail_1_28.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.eflownet.org/viewinfo.cfm?linkcategoryid=4&linkid=64&siteid=1&FuseAction=display</ref> Through implementation of environmental flows, water managers strive to achieve a flow regime, or pattern, that provides for human uses and maintains the essential processes required to support healthy [[river ecosystem]]s. Environmental flows do not necessarily require restoring the natural, pristine flow patterns that would occur absent human development, use, and diversion but, instead, are intended to produce a broader set of values and benefits from rivers than from management focused strictly on water supply, energy, recreation, or [[flood control]].
Rivers are parts of integrated systems that include [[floodplains]] and [[riparian corridor]]s. Collectively these systems provide a large suite of benefits. However, the world's rivers are increasingly being altered through the construction of dams, diversions, and [[levee]]s. More than half of the world's large rivers are dammed,<ref>Nilsson, C., Reidy, C. A., Dynesius, M., and Revenga, C. 2005. Fragmentation and flow regulation of the world's large river systems. Science 308:405-408.</ref> a figure that continues to increase. Almost 1,000 dams are planned or under construction in South America and 50 new dams are planned on China's Yangtze River alone.<ref>[http://www.nature.org/ourinitiatives/habitats/riverslakes/reducing-the-ecological-impact-of-dams.xml Rivers and Lakes: Reducing the Ecological Impact of Dams]</ref> Dams and other river structures change the downstream flow patterns and consequently affect water quality, temperature, sediment movement and deposition, fish and wildlife, and the livelihoods of people who depend on healthy river ecosystems.<ref>Postel, S., and Richter, B. 2003. Rivers for Life: Managing Water for People and Nature. Island Press, Washington, D.C.</ref> Environmental flows seek to maintain these river functions while at the same time providing for traditional offstream benefits.
==Evolution of environmental flow concepts and recognition== From the turn of the 20th century through the 1960s, [[water management]] in [[developed nations]] focused largely on maximizing [[flood protection]], [[water supplies]], and [[hydropower]] generation. During the 1970s, the ecological and economic effects of these projects prompted scientists to seek ways to modify [[dam]] operations to maintain certain fish species. The initial focus was on determining the minimum flow necessary to preserve an individual species, such as [[trout]], in a river. Environmental flows evolved from this concept of "minimum flows" and, later, "instream flows", which emphasized the need to keep water within waterways.
By the 1990s, scientists came to realize that the biological and social systems supported by rivers are too complicated to be summarized by a single minimum flow requirement.<ref>Bunn, S. E., and Arthington, A. H. 2002. Basic principles and ecological consequences of altered flow regimes for aquatic [[biodiversity]]. Environmental Management 30:492-507.</ref><ref>Richter, B., and Thomas, G. A. 2008. {{cite web |url=http://www.waterpowermagazine.com/story.asp?storyCode=2050148 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130209015603/http://www.waterpowermagazine.com/story.asp?storyCode=2050148 |archivedate=2013-02-09 |df= }} Dam Good Operations. International Water Power and Dam Construction July 2008:14-17.</ref> Since the 1990s, restoring and maintaining more comprehensive environmental flows has gained increasing support, as has the capability of scientists and engineers to define these flows to maintain the full spectrum of riverine species, processes and services. Furthermore, implementation has evolved from dam reoperation<ref>Richter, B., and Thomas, G. A. 2008. {{cite web |url=http://www.waterpowermagazine.com/story.asp?storyCode=2050148 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130209015603/http://www.waterpowermagazine.com/story.asp?storyCode=2050148 |archivedate=2013-02-09 |df= }} Dam Good Operations. International Water Power and Dam Construction July 2008:14-17.</ref> to an integration of all aspects of water management,<ref>Dyson, M., Bergkamp, G. J. J., and Scanlon, J., eds. 2003. Flow: The Essentials of Environmental Flows. International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN), Gland, Switzerland, and Cambridge, UK .</ref> including [[groundwater]] and [[surface water]] diversions and return flows, as well as land use and storm water management. The science to support regional-scale environmental flow determination and management has likewise advanced.<ref>Arthington, A. H., Bunn, S. E., Poff, N. L., and Naiman, R. J. 2006. The challenge of providing environmental flow rules to sustain river ecosystems. Ecological Applications 16(4):1311-1318.</ref>
In a global survey of water specialists undertaken in 2003 to gauge perceptions of environmental flow, 88% of the 272 respondents agreed that the concept is essential for sustainably managing [[water resource]]s and meeting the long-term needs of people.<ref>Moore, M. 2004. Perceptions and interpretations of environmental flows and implications for future water resource management: A survey study. Masters Thesis, Department of Water and Environmental Studies, Linköping University, Sweden.</ref> In 2007, the Brisbane Declaration on Environmental Flows was endorsed by more than 750 practitioners from more than 50 countries.<ref>[http://www.eflownet.org/viewinfo.cfm?linkcategoryid=4&linkid=64&siteid=1&FuseAction=display The Brisbane Declaration]</ref> The declaration announced an official pledge to work together to protect and restore the world's rivers and lakes. By 2010, many countries throughout the world had adopted environmental flow policies, although their implementation remains a challenge.<ref>Le Quesne, T., Kendy, E., and Weston, D. 2010. [http://conserveonline.org/workspaces/eloha/documents/wwf-tnc-e-flow-policies-report The Implementation Challenge: Taking stock of government policies to protect and restore environmental flows.] WWF and The Nature Conservancy.</ref>
==Examples== {{See also|Stream restoration}} One effort currently underway to restore environmental flows is the [https://web.archive.org/web/20120321045053/http://www.conservationgateway.org/content/sustainable-rivers Sustainable Rivers Project], a collaboration between [[The Nature Conservancy]] (TNC) and [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] (USACE), which is the largest water manager in the United States. Since 2002, TNC and the USACE have been working to define and implement environmental flows by altering the operations of USACE dams in [https://web.archive.org/web/20120321045155/http://www.conservationgateway.org/file/sustainable-rivers-project-current-sites 8 rivers] across 12 states. Dam reoperation to release environmental flows, in combination with floodplain restoration, has in some instances increased the water available for [[hydropower]] production while reducing flood risk.
[[Arizona]]'s [[Bill Williams River]], flowing downstream of [[Alamo Dam]], is one of the rivers featured in the Sustainable Rivers Project. Having discussed modifying dam operations since the early 1990s, local stakeholders began to work with TNC and USACE in 2005 to identify specific strategies for improving the ecological health and biodiversity of the river basin downstream from the dam. Scientists compiled the best available information and worked together to define [http://www.fort.usgs.gov/products/publications/21745/21745.pdf environmental flows for the Bill Williams River].<ref>U.S. Geological Survey, 2006. Defining Ecosystem Flow Requirements for the Bill Williams River, Arizona. Open-File Report 2006-1314. Edited by Shafroth, P.B. and V.B. Beauchamp.</ref> While not all of the recommended environmental flow components could be implemented immediately, the USACE has changed its operations of Alamo Dam to incorporate more natural low flows and controlled floods. Ongoing monitoring is capturing resulting ecological responses such as rejuvenation of native willow-cottonwood forest, suppression of invasive and non-native tamarisk, restoration of more natural densities of beaver dams and associated lotic-lentic habitat, changes in aquatic insect populations, and enhanced [[groundwater recharge]]. USACE engineers continue to consult with scientists on a regular basis and use the monitoring results to further refine operations of the dam.<ref>Shafroth, P., Wilcox, A., Lytle, D., Hickey, J., Andersen, D., Beauchamp, V., Hautzinger, A., McMullen, L., and Warner, A. 2010. Ecosystem effects of environmental flows: modeling and experimental floods in a dryland river. Freshwater Biology 55: 68-85.</ref>
Another case in which stakeholders developed environmental flow recommendations is [[Honduras]]' [https://web.archive.org/web/20120321045259/http://www.conservationgateway.org/file/sustainable-waters-patuca-river-honduras Patuca III Hydropower Project]. The Patuca River, the second longest river in Central America, has supported fish populations, nourished crops, and enabled navigation for many indigenous communities, including the Tawahka, Pech, and Miskito Indians, for hundreds of years. To protect the ecological health of the largest undisturbed rainforest north of the Amazon and its inhabitants, TNC and [[Empresa Nacional de Energía Eléctrica]] (ENEE, the agency responsible for the project) [https://web.archive.org/web/20120321045259/http://www.conservationgateway.org/file/sustainable-waters-patuca-river-honduras agreed to study] and determine flows necessary to sustain the health of human and natural communities along the river. Due to very limited available data, innovative approaches were developed for estimating flow needs based on experiences and observations of the local people who depend on this nearly pristine river reach.<ref>Esselman, P. C., and Opperman, J. J. 2010. [http://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol15/iss1/art6/ Overcoming information limitations] for the prescription of an environmental flow regime for a Central American river. Ecology and Society 15(1):6 (online).</ref>
==Methods, tools, and models== More than 200 methods are used worldwide to prescribe river flows needed to maintain healthy rivers. However, very few of these are comprehensive and holistic, accounting for seasonal and inter-annual flow variation needed to support the whole range of [[ecosystem services]] that healthy rivers provide.<ref>Tharme, R. E. 2003. A global perspective on environmental flow assessment: emerging trends in the development and application of environmental flow methodologies for rivers. River Research and Applications 19:397-441.</ref> Such comprehensive approaches include DRIFT (Downstream Response to Imposed Flow Transformation),<ref>King, J., Brown, C., and Sabet, H. 2003. A scenario-based holistic approach to environmental flow assessments for rivers. River Research and Applications 19(5-6):619-639.</ref> BBM (Building Block Methodology),<ref>King, J., and Louw, D. 1998. Instream flow assessments for regulated rivers in South Africa using the Building Block Methodology. Aquatic Ecosystem Health and Management 1:109-124.</ref> and the "Savannah Process"<ref>Richter, B. D., Warner, A. T., Meyer, J. L., and Lutz, K. 2006. A collaborative and adaptive process for developing environmental flow recommendations. River Research and Applications 22:297-318.</ref> for site-specific environmental flow assessment, and ELOHA (Ecological Limits of Hydrologic Alteration) for regional-scale water resource planning and management.<ref>Poff, N. L., Richter, B. D., Arthington, A. H., Bunn, S. E., Naiman, R. J., Kendy, E., Acreman, M., Apse, C., Bledsoe, B. P., Freeman, M. C., Henriksen, J., Jacobson, R. B., Kennen, J. G., Merritt, D. M., O'Keeffe, J. H., Olden, J. D., Rogers, K., Tharme, R. E., and Warner, A. 2010. The ecological limits of hydrologic alteration (ELOHA): a new framework for developing regional environmental flow standards. Freshwater Biology 55:147-170.</ref> The "best" method, or more likely, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120321045413/http://www.conservationgateway.org/content/environmental-flows-methods-and-tools methods], for a given situation depends on the amount of resources and data available, the most important issues, and the level of certainty required. To facilitate environmental flow prescriptions, a number of computer models and tools have been developed by groups such as the USACE's [http://www.hec.usace.army.mil/ Hydrologic Engineering Center] to capture flow requirements defined in a workshop setting (e.g., [http://www.hec.usace.army.mil/software/hec-rpt/ HEC-RPT]) or to evaluate the implications of environmental flow implementation (e.g., [http://www.hec.usace.army.mil/software/hec-ressim/ HEC-ResSim], [http://www.hec.usace.army.mil/software/hec-ras/ HEC-RAS], and [http://www.hec.usace.army.mil/software/hec-efm/index.html HEC-EFM]). Additionally, a [[2D geometric model|2D]] model is developed from a [[3D modeling|3D]] turbulence model based on Smagorinsky large eddy closure to more appropriately model environmental large scale flows.<ref>Cao, M. and Roberts, A. J. 2012. Modelling 3D turbulent floods based upon the Smagorinski large eddy closure. Proceedings of the 18th Australasian Fluid Mechanics Conference Published by the Australasian Fluid Mechanics Society.</ref> This model is based on a [[slow manifold]] of the turbulent Smagorinsky large eddy closure instead of conventional depth-averaging flow equations.
Other tried and tested environmental flow assessment methods include DRIFT (King et al. 2003), which was recently used in the Kishenganga HPP dispute between Pakistan and India at the International Court of Arbitration.
==In India==
In [[India]], the need for environmental flows has emerged from the hundreds of large [[dams]] being planned in the [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] rivers for hydro power generation. The cascades of dams planned across the [[Lohit district|Lohit]], [[Dibang River]] in the [[Brahmaputra River]] , the [[Alaknanda River|Alaknanda]] and [[Bhagirathi River]] in the [[Ganga river|Ganga]] basin and the [[Teesta River|Teesta]] in [[Sikkim]] for example, would end up in the rivers flowing more through tunnels and pen stocks rather than the river channels. There have been some recommendations by various authorities (Courts, Tribunals, Expert Appraisal Committee of the [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)]]) on releasing e-flows from dams. However, these recommendations have never been backed by strong objectives about why certain e-flow releases are needed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.internationalrivers.org/files/attached-files/eflows_primer_062012.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710223754/http://www.internationalrivers.org/files/attached-files/eflows_primer_062012.pdf |archivedate=2012-07-10 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Freshwater inflow]]
==References== <references/>
{{Aquatic ecosystem topics}}
[[Category:Rivers]] [[Category:Aquatic ecology]]

[[File:Structure of mammalian eIF3 in the context of the 43S preinitiation complex PDB 5A5T.jpg|300px|thumbnail|Structure of rabbit eIF3 in the context of the 43S PIC, showing subunits a, c, e, f, h, k, l, and m.<ref name="Georges">{{Cite journal|title = Structure of mammalian eIF3 in the context of the 43S preinitiation complex|journal = Nature|year = 2015|url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v525/n7570/full/nature14891.html|issn = 0028-0836|pmid = 26344199 |pages = 491–5|volume = 525|issue=1770|doi=10.1038/nature14891|language = en|first = Amedee |last =des Georges |first2 = Vidya|last2 =Dhote|first3 = Lauriane|last3 = Kuhn|first4 =Christopher U.T.|last4 = Hellen|first5 = Tatyana V.|last5 = Pestova |first6 = Joachim|last6 = Frank|first7 = Yaser|last7 = Hashem|pmc = 4719162}}</ref>]]
'''Eukaryotic initiation factor 3''' ('''eIF3''') is a [[multiprotein complex]] that functions during the initiation phase of [[eukaryotic translation]].<ref name="Aitken">{{cite journal|last1=Aitken|first1=Colin E.|last2=Lorsch|first2=Jon R.|title=A mechanistic overview of translation initiation in eukaryotes|journal=Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol.|date=2012|volume=19|issue=6|pages=568–576|doi=10.1038/nsmb.2303|pmid=22664984|url=http://www.nature.com/nsmb/journal/v19/n6/full/nsmb.2303.html|accessdate=20 February 2016}}</ref> It is essential for most forms of [[Eukaryotic translation#cap-dependent initiation|cap-dependent]] and [[Eukaryotic translation#cap-independent|cap-independent]] translation initiation. In humans, eIF3 consists of 13 nonidentical subunits (eIF3a-m) with a combined molecular weight of ~800 kDa, making it the largest [[Eukaryotic initiation factor|translation initiation factor]].<ref name="Hershey">{{Cite journal|title = The role of eIF3 and its individual subunits in cancer|journal = Biochim. Biophys. Acta|year = 2015|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1874939914002715|issn = 1874-9399|pmid = 25450521 |pages = 792–800|volume = 1849|doi=10.1016/j.bbagrm.2014.10.005|language = en|first = John W.B.|last = Hershey}}</ref> The eIF3 complex is broadly conserved across eukaryotes, but the conservation of individual subunits varies across organisms. For instance, while most mammalian eIF3 complexes are composed of 13 subunits, [[Saccharomyces cerevisiae|budding yeast's]] eIF3 has only six subunits (eIF3a, b, c, g, i, j).<ref name="Hinnebusch">{{Cite journal|title = eIF3: a versatile scaffold for translation initiation complexes|journal = Trends Biochem. Sci. |year = 2006|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0968000406002271|issn = 0968-0004|pmid = 16920360|pages = 553–562|volume = 31|issue = 10|doi=10.1016/j.tibs.2006.08.005|language = en|first = Alan G.|last = Hinnebusch}}</ref>
== Function == eIF3 stimulates nearly all steps of translation initiation.<ref name="Hinnebusch"/> eIF3 also appears to participate in other phases of translation, such as recycling, where it promotes the splitting of post-termination ribosomes.<ref name=Pisarev>{{cite journal|last1=Pisarev|first1=Andrey V.|last2=Hellen|first2=Christopher U. T.|last3=Pestova|first3=Tatyana V.|title=Recycling of eukaryotic post-termination ribosomal complexes|journal=Cell|date=2007|volume=131|issue=2|pages=286–99|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2007.08.041|pmid=17956730|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0092-8674(07)01138-5|accessdate=5 January 2016|pmc=2651563}}</ref> In specialized cases of reinitiation following [[Upstream Open Reading Frame|uORFs]], eIF3 may remain bound to the ribosome through elongation and termination to promote subsequent initiation events.<ref name="Sonenberg/Hinnebusch Review">{{cite journal|last1=Sonenberg|first1=Nahum|last2=Hinnebusch|first2=Alan G.|title=Regulation of Translation Initiation in Eukaryotes: Mechanisms and Biological Targets|journal=Cell|date=2009|volume=136|pages=731–745|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2009.01.042|pmid=19239892|url=http://www.cell.com/abstract/S0092-8674(09)00090-7|accessdate=19 February 2016|pmc=3610329}}</ref> Research has also indicated that eIF3 plays a role in programmed [[Stop codon#Translational readthrough|stop codon readthrough]] in yeast, by interacting with pre-termination complexes and interfering with decoding.<ref name="Beznoskova">{{cite journal|last1=Beznoskova|first1=Petra|last2=Wagner|first2=Susan|last3=Jansen|first3=Myrte Esmeralda|last4=von der Haar|first4=Tobias|last5=Valasek|first5=Leos Shivaya|title=Translation initiation factor eIF3 promotes programmed stop codon readthrough|journal=Nucleic Acids Res.|date=2015|volume=43|issue=10|pages=5099–5111|doi=10.1093/nar/gkv421|pmid=25925566|url=http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/10/5099.long|accessdate=27 February 2016|pmc=4446449}}</ref>
== Interactions == eIF3 binds the [[Eukaryotic small ribosomal subunit (40S)|small ribosomal subunit (40S)]] at and near its solvent side and serves as a scaffold for several other initiation factors, the auxiliary factor [[DHX29]], and [[mRNA]]. eIF3 is a component of the multifactor complex (MFC) and [[43S preinitiation complex|43S]] and [[48S preinitiation complex|48S]] preinitiation complexes (PICs).<ref name="Hinnebusch"/> The interactions of eIF3 with other initiation factors can vary amongst species; for example, mammalian eIF3 directly interacts with the [[Eukaryotic initiation factor 4F|eIF4F]] complex (via [[eIF4G]]), while budding yeast lacks this connection.<ref name="Hinnebusch"/> However, both mammalian and yeast eIF3 independently bind [[eIF1]], [[eIF4B]], and [[eIF5]].<ref name="Aitken"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jackson|first1=Richard J.|last2=Hellen|first2=Christopher U. T.|last3=Pestova|first3=Tatyana V.|title=The mechanism of eukaryotic translation initiation and principles of its regulation|journal=Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol.|date=2010|volume=11|pages=113–127|doi=10.1038/nrm2838|pmid=20094052|url=http://www.nature.com/nrm/journal/v11/n2/full/nrm2838.html|accessdate=23 February 2016|pmc=4461372}}</ref>
Several subunits of eIF3 contain [[RNA recognition motif|RNA recognition motifs (RRMs)]] and other RNA binding domains to form a multisubunit RNA binding interface through which eIF3 interacts with cellular and viral [[Internal ribosome entry site|IRES]] mRNA, including the [[HCV IRES]].<ref name="Hinnebusch"/> eIF3 has also been shown to specifically bind [[N6-Methyladenosine|m<sup>6</sup>A]] modified RNA within [[Five prime untranslated region|5'UTRs]] to promote cap-independent translation.<ref name=Meyer>{{cite journal|last1=Meyer|first1=Kate D.|last2=Patil|first2=Deepak P.|last3=Zhou|first3=Jun|last4=Zinoviev|first4=Alexandra|last5=Skabkin|first5=Maxim A.|last6=Elemento|first6=Olivier|last7=Pestova|first7=Tatyana V.|last8=Qiang|first8=Shu-Bing|last9=Jaffrey|first9=Samie R.|title=5' UTR m6A Promotes Cap-Independent Translation|journal=Cell|date=November 2015|volume=163|pages=999–1010|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2015.10.012|pmid=26593424|url=http://www.cell.com/cell/abstract/S0092-8674(15)01325-2|accessdate=10 January 2016}}</ref>
All five core subunits of budding yeast's eIF3 are present in heat-induced [[stress granule]]s, along with several other translation factors.<ref name="Wallace">{{cite journal|last1=Wallace|first1=Edward W.J.|last2=Kear-Scott|first2=Jamie L.|last3=Pilipenko|first3=Evgeny V.|last4=Schwartz|first4=Michael H.|last5=Laskowsk|first5=Pawel R.|last6=Rojek|first6=Alexander E.|last7=Katansk|first7=Christopher D.|last8=Riback|first8=Joshua A.|last9=Dion|first9=Michael F.|last10=Franks|first10=Alexander M.|authorlink11=Edoardo Airoldi|last11=Airoldi|first11=Edoardo M.|last12=Pan|first12=Tao|last13=Budnik|first13=Bogdan A.|last14=Drummond|first14=D. Allan|title=Reversible, Specific, Active Aggregates of Endogenous Proteins Assemble upon Heat Stress|journal=Cell|date=2015|volume=162|issue=6|pages=1286–1298|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2015.08.041|pmid=26359986|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867415010934|accessdate=26 February 2016|pmc=4567705}}</ref>
== Structure == A functional eIF3 complex can be purified from native sources, or reconstituted from recombinantly expressed subunits.<ref name=Zhou>{{cite journal|last1=Zhou|first1=Min|last2=Sandercock|first2=Alan M.|last3=Fraser|first3=Christopher S.|last4=Ridlova|first4=Gabriela|last5=Stephens|first5=Elaine|last6=Schenauer|first6=Matthew R.|last7=Yokoi-Fong|first7=Theresa|last8=Barsky|first8=Daniel|last9=Leary|first9=Julie A.|last10=Hershey|first10=John W.|last11=Doudna|first11=Jennifer A.|last12=Robinson|first12=Carol V.|title=Mass spectrometry reveals modularity and a complete subunit interaction map of the eukaryotic translation factor eIF3|journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci.|date=Nov 2008|volume=105|issue=47|pages=18139–44|doi=10.1073/pnas.0801313105|pmid=18599441|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/105/47/18139.long|accessdate=6 January 2016|pmc=2587604}}</ref><ref name=Sun>{{cite journal|last1=Sun|first1=Chaomin|last2=Todorovic|first2=Aleksandar|last3=Querol-Audi|first3=Jordi|last4=Bai|first4=Yun|last5=Villa|first5=Nancy|last6=Snyder|first6=Monica|last7=Ashchyan|first7=John|last8=Lewis|first8=Christopher S.|last9=Hartland|first9=Abbey|last10=Gradia|first10=Scott|last11=Fraser|first11=Christopher S.|last12=Doudna|first12=Jennifer A.|last13=Nogales|first13=Eva|last14=Cate|first14=Jamie H. D.|title=Functional reconstitution of human eukaryotic translation initiation factor 3 (eIF3)|journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci.|date=2011|volume=108|issue=51|pages=20473–20478|doi=10.1073/pnas.1116821108|pmid=22135459|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/51/20473.long|accessdate=19 February 2016|pmc=3251073}}</ref> Individual subunits have been structurally characterized by [[X-ray crystallography]] and [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy of proteins|NMR]], while complexes have been characterized by [[Cryo-electron microscopy|Cryo-EM]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Liu|first1=Yi|last2=Neumann|first2=Piotr|last3=Kuhle|first3=Berhard|last4=Monecke|first4=Thomas|last5=Schell|first5=Stephanie|last6=Chari|first6=Ashwin|last7=Ficner|first7=Ralph|title=Translation Initiation Factor eIF3b Contains a Nine-Bladed b-Propeller and Interacts with the 40S Ribosomal Subunit|journal=Structure|date=2014|volume=22|pages=923–930|doi=10.1016/j.str.2014.03.010|pmid=24768115|url=http://www.cell.com/structure/abstract/S0969-2126(14)00082-3?_returnURL=http%3A%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2FS0969212614000823%3Fshowall%3Dtrue|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=ElAntak|first1=Latifa|last2=Wagner|first2=Susan|last3=Herrmannova|first3=Anna|last4=Karaskova|first4=Martina|last5=Rutkai|first5=Edit|last6=Lukavsky|first6=Peter J.|last7=Valasek|first7=Leos|title=The Indispensable N-Terminal Half of eIF3j/HCR1 Cooperates with its Structurally Conserved Binding Partner eIF3b/PRT1-RRM and with eIF1A in Stringent AUG Selection|journal=J. Mol. Biol.|date=2010|volume=396|pages=1097–1116|doi=10.1016/j.jmb.2009.12.047|pmid=20060839|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S002228360901554X|accessdate=19 February 2016|pmc=2824034}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Siridechadilok|first1=Bunpote|last2=Fraser|first2=Christopher S.|last3=Hall|first3=Richard J.|last4=Doudna|first4=Jennifer A.|last5=Nogales|first5=Eva|title=Structural Roles for Human Translation Factor eIF3 in Initiation of Protein Synthesis|journal=Science|date=2005|volume=310|pages=1513–1515|doi=10.1126/science.1118977|pmid=16322461|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/310/5753/1513.long|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> No structure of complete human eIF3 is available, but the nearly-full complex has been determined at medium resolution in the context of the 43S PIC.<ref name="Georges"/> The structural core of mammalian eIF3 is often described as a five-lobed particle with anthropomorphic features, composed largely of the PCI/MPN octamer.<ref name="Sun"/> The PCI domains are named for structural similarities between the [[proteasome]] cap (P), the [[COP9 signalosome]] (C), and eIF3 (I), while the MPN domains are named for structural similarity to the Mpr1-PadI N-terminal domains.<ref name="Sun"/>
== Signaling == eIF3 serves as a hub for cellular signaling through [[P70-S6 Kinase 1|S6K1]] and [[mTORC1|mTOR]]/[[RPTOR|Raptor]].<ref name="Holz">{{cite journal|last1=Holz|first1=Marina K.|last2=Ballif|first2=Bryan A.|last3=Gygi|first3=Steven P.|last4=Blenis|first4=John|title=mTOR and S6K1 Mediate Assembly of the Translation Preinitiation Complex through Dynamic Protein Interchange and Ordered Phosphorylation Events|journal=Cell|date=2005|volume=123|pages=569–580|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2005.10.024|pmid=16286006|url=http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(05)01157-8|accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> In particular, eIF3 is bound by S6K1 in its inactive state, and activated mTOR/Raptor binds to eIF3 and phosphorylates S6K1 to promote its release from eIF3. Phosphorylated S6K1 is then free to phosphorylate a number of its own targets, including [[eIF4B]], thus serving as a mechanism of translational control.
== Disease == Individual subunits of eIF3 are overexpressed (a, b, c, h, i, and m) and underexpressed (e, f) in multiple human cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> eIF3 has also been shown to bind a specific set of cell proliferation mRNAs and regulate their translation.<ref name=Lee>{{Cite journal|title = eIF3 targets cell-proliferation messenger RNAs for translational activation or repression|journal = Nature|year = 2015|url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v522/n7554/full/nature14267.html|issn = 0028-0836|pmid = 25849773 |pages = 111–114|volume = 522|doi=10.1038/nature14267|language = en|first = Amy S.Y.|last = Lee|first2 = Philip J.|last2 = Kranusch|first3 = Jamie H.D.|last3 = Cate|pmc=4603833}}</ref> eIF3 also functions in the life cycles of a number of important human pathogens, including [[HIV]] and [[Hepatitis C virus|HCV]]. In particular, the d-subunit of eIF3 is a substrate of [[HIV-1 protease|HIV protease]], and genetic knockdown of eIF3 subunits d, e, or f results in increased viral infectivity for unknown reasons.<ref name="JägerCimermancic2011">{{cite journal|last1=Jäger|first1=Stefanie|last2=Cimermancic|first2=Peter|last3=Gulbahce|first3=Natali|last4=Johnson|first4=Jeffrey R.|last5=McGovern|first5=Kathryn E.|last6=Clarke|first6=Starlynn C.|last7=Shales|first7=Michael|last8=Mercenne|first8=Gaelle|last9=Pache|first9=Lars|last10=Li|first10=Kathy|last11=Hernandez|first11=Hilda|last12=Jang|first12=Gwendolyn M.|last13=Roth|first13=Shoshannah L.|last14=Akiva|first14=Eyal|last15=Marlett|first15=John|last16=Stephens|first16=Melanie|last17=D’Orso|first17=Ivan|last18=Fernandes|first18=Jason|last19=Fahey|first19=Marie|last20=Mahon|first20=Cathal|last21=O’Donoghue|first21=Anthony J.|last22=Todorovic|first22=Aleksandar|last23=Morris|first23=John H.|last24=Maltby|first24=David A.|last25=Alber|first25=Tom|last26=Cagney|first26=Gerard|last27=Bushman|first27=Frederic D.|last28=Young|first28=John A.|last29=Chanda|first29=Sumit K.|last30=Sundquist|first30=Wesley I.|last31=Kortemme|first31=Tanja|last32=Hernandez|first32=Ryan D.|last33=Craik|first33=Charles S.|last34=Burlingame|first34=Alma|last35=Sali|first35=Andrej|last36=Frankel|first36=Alan D.|last37=Krogan|first37=Nevan J.|title=Global landscape of HIV–human protein complexes|journal=Nature|year=2011|issn=0028-0836|doi=10.1038/nature10719|pmid=22190034|pmc=3310911|volume=481|pages=365–70}}</ref>
== Subunits == The eIF3 subunits exist at equal [[stoichiometry]] within the complex, with the exception of [[eIF3J]], which is loosely bound and non-essential for viability in several species.<ref name="Zhou"/><ref name=Valasek>{{cite journal|last1=Valasek|first1=Leos|last2=Hasek|first2=Jiri|last3=Trachsel|first3=Hans|last4=Imre|first4=Esther Maria|last5=Ruis|first5=Helmut|title=The Saccharomyces cerevisiae HCR1 Gene Encoding a Homologue of the p35 Subunit of Human Translation Initiation Factor 3 (eIF3) Is a High Copy Suppressor of a Temperature-sensitive Mutation in the Rpg1p Subunit of Yeast eIF3|journal=J. Biol. Chem.|date=1999|volume=274|issue=39|pages=27567–72|doi=10.1074/jbc.274.39.27567|pmid=10488093|url=http://www.jbc.org/content/274/39/27567.long}}</ref><ref name=Smith>{{cite journal|last1=Smith|first1=M. Duane|last2=Yu|first2=Gu|last3=Querol-Audí|first3=Jordi|last4=Vogan|first4=Jacob M.|last5=Nitido|first5=Adam|last6=Cate|first6=Jamie H.D.|title=Human-Like Eukaryotic Translation Initiation Factor 3 from Neurospora crassa|journal=PLoS ONE |date=November 2013|volume=8|issue=11|page=e78715|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0078715|pmid=24250809|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0078715|accessdate=10 January 2016|pmc=3826745}}</ref> The subunits were originally organized alphabetically by molecular weight in mammals (A as the highest), but the arrangement of molecular weight can vary between species.<ref name=Browning>{{cite journal|last1=Browning|first1=Karen S.|last2=Gallie|first2=Daniel R.|last3=Hershey|first3=John W.B.|last4=Maitra|first4=Umadas|last5=Merrick|first5=William C.|last6=Norbury|first6=Chris|title=Unified nomenclature for the subunits of eukaryotic initiation factor 3|journal=Trends Biochem. Sci.|date=May 2001|volume=26|issue=5|page=284|doi=10.1016/S0968-0004(01)01825-4|pmid=11426420|url=http://www.cell.com/trends/biochemical-sciences/abstract/S0968-0004(01)01825-4?_returnURL=http%3A%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2FS0968000401018254%3Fshowall%3Dtrue|accessdate=10 January 2016}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Subunit !! MW (kDa){{ref label|rounding|A|A}} !! Key Features |- | [[eIF3A|A]] || 167 || Upregulated in several human cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> Crosslinks directly to cellular mRNA.<ref name="Lee"/> Contains PCI domain.<ref name="Sun"/> |- | [[EIF3B|B]] || 92 || Upregulated in several cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> Crosslinks directly to cellular mRNA.<ref name="Lee"/> Contains RRM.<ref name="Zhou"/> |- | [[EIF3C|C]] || 105 || Upregulated in several cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> Contains PCI domain.<ref name="Sun"/> |- | [[EIF3D|D]] || 64 || Dispensable for growth in [[Schizosaccharomyces pombe|fission yeast]].<ref name="Hinnebusch"/> Crosslinks directly to cellular mRNA<ref name="Lee"/> and binds the [[Five-prime cap|5'cap]] of select mRNAs<ref name="Lee Kranzusch Doudna Cate pp. 96–99">{{cite journal | last=Lee | first=Amy S. Y. | last2=Kranzusch | first2=Philip J. | last3=Doudna | first3=Jennifer A. | last4=Cate | first4=Jamie H. D. | title=eIF3d is an mRNA cap-binding protein that is required for specialized translation initiation | journal=Nature | publisher=Springer Nature | volume=536 | issue=7614 | date=2016-07-27 | issn=0028-0836 | doi=10.1038/nature18954 | pages=96–99| pmc=5003174 }}</ref>. Substrate of HIV protease.<ref name="JägerCimermancic2011"/> |- | [[EIF3S6|E]] || 52 || Downregulated in breast and lung cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> Nonessential for growth in fission yeast<ref name="Akiyoshi Clayton Phan Yamamoto pp. 10056–10062">{{cite journal | last=Akiyoshi | first=Yuji | last2=Clayton | first2=Jason | last3=Phan | first3=Lon | last4=Yamamoto | first4=Masayuki | last5=Hinnebusch | first5=Alan G. | last6=Watanabe | first6=Yoshinori | last7=Asano | first7=Katsura | title=Fission Yeast Homolog of Murine Int-6 Protein, Encoded by Mouse Mammary Tumor Virus Integration Site, Is Associated with the Conserved Core Subunits of Eukaryotic Translation Initiation Factor 3 | journal=Journal of Biological Chemistry | publisher=American Society for Biochemistry & Molecular Biology (ASBMB) | volume=276 | issue=13 | date=2000-12-27 | issn=0021-9258 | doi=10.1074/jbc.m010188200 | pages=10056–10062}}</ref> and ''[[Neurospora crassa]]''<ref name="Smith"/>. Contains PCI domain.<ref name="Sun"/> |- | [[EIF3F|F]] || 38 || Downregulated in several cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> Contains MPN domain.<ref name="Sun"/> |- | [[EIF3G|G]] || 36 || Contains RRM.<ref name="Zhou"/> Crosslinks directly to cellular mRNA.<ref name="Lee"/> |- | [[EIF3H|H]] || 40 || Upregulated in several cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> Nonessential for growth in fission yeast<ref name="Ray Bandyopadhyay Matsumoto Deng 2008 pp. 809–823">{{cite journal | last=Ray | first=Anirban | last2=Bandyopadhyay | first2=Amitabha | last3=Matsumoto | first3=Tomohiro | last4=Deng | first4=Haiteng | last5=Maitra | first5=Umadas | title=Fission yeast translation initiation factor 3 subunit eIF3h is not essential for global translation initiation, but deletion ofeif3h+affects spore formation | journal=Yeast | publisher=Wiley-Blackwell | volume=25 | issue=11 | year=2008 | issn=0749-503X | doi=10.1002/yea.1635 | pages=809–823}}</ref>, ''Neurospora crassa''<ref name="Smith"/>, and human cell lines<ref name="Smith Arake-Tacca Nitido Montabana 2016 pp. 886–896">{{cite journal | last=Smith | first=M. Duane | last2=Arake-Tacca | first2=Luisa | last3=Nitido | first3=Adam | last4=Montabana | first4=Elizabeth | last5=Park | first5=Annsea | last6=Cate | first6=Jamie H. | title=Assembly of eIF3 Mediated by Mutually Dependent Subunit Insertion | journal=Structure | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=24 | issue=6 | year=2016 | issn=0969-2126 | doi=10.1016/j.str.2016.02.024 | pages=886–896}}</ref><ref name="Johnson Petrov Fuchs Majzoub p. ">{{cite journal | last=Johnson | first=Alex G. | last2=Petrov | first2=Alexey N. | last3=Fuchs | first3=Gabriele | last4=Majzoub | first4=Karim | last5=Grosely | first5=Rosslyn | last6=Choi | first6=Junhong | last7=Puglisi | first7=Joseph D. | title=Fluorescently-tagged human eIF3 for single-molecule spectroscopy | journal=Nucleic Acids Research | publisher=Oxford University Press (OUP) | date=2017-11-09 | issn=0305-1048 | doi=10.1093/nar/gkx1050 | page=}}</ref>. Contains MPN domain.<ref name="Sun"/> |- | [[EIF3I|I]] || 36 || Upregulated in several cancers.<ref name="Hershey"/> |- | [[eIF3J|J]] || 29 || Loosely bound, non-stoichiometric subunit.<ref name="Hinnebusch"/> Binds the 40S ribosomal subunit within the decoding center.<ref name="Fraser">{{cite journal|last1=Fraser|first1=Christopher S.|last2=Berry|first2=Katherine E.|last3=Hershey|first3=John W. B.|last4=Doudna|first4=Jennifer A.|title=eIF3j Is Located in the Decoding Center of the Human 40S Ribosomal Subunit|journal=Molecular Cell|date=2007|volume=26|pages=811–819|doi=10.1016/j.molcel.2007.05.019|pmid=17588516|url=http://www.cell.com/molecular-cell/abstract/S1097-2765(07)00320-6|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> Nonessential for growth in budding yeast.<ref name="Hinnebusch"/> |- | [[EIF3K|K]] || 25 || Nonessential for growth in ''Neurospora crassa''.<ref name="Smith"/> Contains PCI domain.<ref name="Sun"/> |- | [[EIF3EIP|L]]|| 67 || Nonessential for growth in ''Neurospora crassa''.<ref name="Smith"/> Contains PCI domain.<ref name="Sun"/> |- | [[EIF3M|M]] || 43 || Upregulated in human colon cancer.<ref name="Hershey"/> |} {{note label|rounding|A|A}}Molecular weight of human subunits.
