{{nofootnotes|date=July 2010}} '''Private jurisdiction''' is the right of an individual or a [[Legal person|legal entity]] to establish [[Court|courts of law]]. It was prevalent during [[feudalism]].
A [[Exclusive right|franchise]], such as a [[corporation]], a jurisdiction, or a right to collect certain tolls or taxes, was, in effect, a kind of property: an "[[incorporeal hereditament]]". Under [[English law]] incorporeal hereditaments (including jurisdictions) were either granted or recognized in [[charter]]s.
Franchise jurisdictions included those of [[manorial court]]s, secular courts of ecclesiastical corporations (in addition to the Church's own jurisdiction over [[family law]]), [[borough courts]] of [[municipal corporation]]s, merchant courts established on markets and fairs, and mining courts of mines and mining villages.
In medieval England franchises could also be established for jurisdiction over partially or entirely privatized administrative territories such as "[[Hundred (county subdivision)|hundreds]]" and [[county|counties]]. Broad jurisdictional powers were also granted to many colonial corporations (such as the [[East India Company]]).
In medieval England for many substantive areas of law the king's courts only reviewed whether the franchise courts stayed within their jurisdictional and certain procedural bounds and not the substance of the case. Generally, the only way to remove or undo the remedy of a franchise court case in royal court was to bring one of several varieties of lawsuits for [[trespass]] ([[tort]]) against the franchise court. ==See also== *[[High, middle and low justice]] *[[Zwing und Bann]] *[[Court baron]] *[[Court leet]]
==External links== *[http://unenumerated.blogspot.com/2006/06/jurisdiction-as-property-paper.html Jurisdiction as property] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091001030343/http://szabo.best.vwh.net/JurisdictionAsProperty.pdf Jurisdiction as Property: Franchise Jurisdiction from Henry III to James I by Nicholas J. Szabo] [[Category:Jurisdiction| ]] [[Category:Feudalism]] [[Category:Legal history]]

'''QPNC-PAGE''', or '''quantitative preparative native continuous polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis''', is a bioanalytical, high-resolution and highly [[Accuracy and precision|accurate]] [[Scientific technique|technique]] applied in [[biochemistry]] and [[bioinorganic chemistry]] to separate [[protein]]s quantitatively by [[isoelectric point]]. This standardized variant of native [[gel electrophoresis]] was developed for determining the three-dimensional structure of [[biology|biological]] macromolecules in solution, for example, active or [[native state|native]] [[metalloprotein]]s in biological [[Sample (material)|sample]]s or properly and improperly [[protein folding|folded]] metal [[Cofactor (biochemistry)|cofactor]]-containing proteins or [[protein isoform]]s in complex protein [[mixture]]s, to understand their function in the cell.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Electrophoresis |date=2008 |volume=29 |pages=2617–36 |title=Preparative isolation of protein complexes and other bioparticles by elution from polyacrylamide gels |vauthors=Seelert H, Krause F |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/elps.200800061/abstract |doi=10.1002/elps.200800061 |pmid=18494038 |issue=12 }} </ref>
==Introduction==
Proteins perform several functions in [[life|living]] [[organism]]s, including [[Catalysis|catalytic]] reactions and transport of [[molecule]]s or [[ion]]s within the [[Cell (biology)|cell]]s, the [[Organ (anatomy)|organs]] or the whole [[Human body|body]]. The understanding of the [[biological process|processes]] in human organisms, which are mainly driven by [[Chemical reaction|biochemical reactions]] and [[protein-protein interaction]]s, depends to a great extent on our ability to isolate active proteins in biological samples for more detailed examination of chemical [[structure]] and [[Physiology|physiological]] function. This essential [[information]] can imply an important indication of a [[patient]]'s state of [[health]].<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Analytical Atomic Spectrometry |year=2016 |volume=31 |pages=1756–65 |title=Update on the status of metrology for metalloproteins |vauthors=Swart C, Jakubowski N |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2016/ja/c6ja00181e#!divAbstract |doi=10.1039/C6JA00181E |pmid= |pmc= |issue=9 }}</ref>
As about 30-40% of all known proteins contain one or more [[metallome|metal ion cofactors]] (e.g., [[ceruloplasmin]], [[ferritin]], [[amyloid precursor protein]], [[matrix metalloproteinase]]), especially native metalloproteins have to be isolated, identified and quantified after [[liquid biopsy]]. Many of these cofactors (e.g., [[iron]], [[copper]], or [[zinc]]) play a key role in vital [[enzyme|enzymatic]] catalytic processes or stabilize [[globular protein]] molecules.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Science |year=2003 |volume=300 |pages=931–6 |title=Transition metal speciation in the cell: insights from the chemistry of metal ion receptors |vauthors=Finney LA, O'Halloran TV |url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/300/5621/931 |doi=10.1126/science.1085049 |pmid=12738850 |pmc= |issue=5621 |bibcode=2003Sci...300..931F }}</ref> Therefore, the high-precision [[electrophoresis]] and other native [[Separation process|separation]] techniques are highly relevant as initial step of [[Proteomics|protein]] and trace metal speciation analysis, subsequently followed by [[Mass spectrometry|mass spectrometric]] and [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy of proteins|magnetic resonance]] methods for quantifying and identifying the [[Solution|soluble]] proteins of interest.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Metallomics |year=2013 |volume=5 |pages=1336–45 |title=Analytical methods for copper, zinc and iron quantification in mammalian cells |vauthors=Cerchiaro G, Manieri TM, Bertuchi FR |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlehtml/2013/mt/c3mt00136a |doi=10.1039/c3mt00136a |pmid=23925479 |pmc= |issue=10 }}</ref>
==Method==
===Separation and buffering mechanisms===
[[File:Electrphoresis Tools.TIF|thumb|255px|''Equipment'' for analytical electrophoresis: electrophoresis chamber, peristaltic pump, fraction collector, buffer recirculation pump and UV detector (in a refrigerator), power supply and recorder (on a table)]] In gel electrophoresis proteins are normally separated by [[Electric charge|charge]], [[Molecular mass|size]], or [[Protein structure|shape]]. The aim of [[isoelectric focusing]] (IEF), for example, is to separate proteins according to their isoelectric point (pI), thus, according to their charge at different [[pH]] values.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Methods in Enzymology |date=1990 |volume=182 |pages=459–77 |title=Isoelectric focusing |author=Garfin DE |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0076687990820373 |doi=10.1016/0076-6879(90)82037-3 |pmid=2314254 |pmc= |issue= }} </ref> Here, the same mechanism is accomplished in a commercially available electrophoresis chamber (see figure ''Equipment'') for separating [[zwitterions|charged]] [[biomolecule]]s, for example, [[superoxide dismutase]] (SOD)<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Biochemical Journal |date=1996 |volume=318 |pages=889–96 |title=A novel nickel-containing superoxide dismutase from Streptomyces spp |vauthors=Youn HD, Kim EJ, Roe JH, Hah YC, Kang SO |url=http://www.biochemj.org/content/318/3/889 |doi= |pmid=8836134 |pmc=1217701 |issue=Pt 3 }} </ref> or [[allergen]]s,<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Electrophoresis |date=2004 |volume=25 |pages=14–9 |title=Analytical and preparative native polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis: investigation of the recombinant and natural major grass pollen allergen Phl p 2 |vauthors=Suck R, Petersen A, Weber B, Fiebig H, Cromwell O |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/elps.200305697/abstract |doi=10.1002/elps.200305697 |pmid=14730563 |pmc= |issue=1 }} </ref> at continuous pH conditions and different velocities of migration depending on different isoelectric points. The separated (metal) proteins [[Elution|elute]] sequentially, starting with the lowest (pI > 2-4) and ending with the highest pI (pI < 10.0) of the present protein molecules.
Due to the specific properties of the prepared gel and electrophoresis [[buffer solution]] (which is [[Base (chemistry)|basic]] and contains [[Tris]]-[[HCl]] and [[Sodium azide|NaN<sub>3</sub>]]), most proteins of a [[biological system]] (e.g., ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]''<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Proteomics |date=2003 |volume=3 |pages=569–79 |title=Strategies for the enrichment and identification of basic proteins in proteome projects |vauthors=Bae SH, Harris AG, Hains PG, Chen H, Garfin DE, Hazell SL, Paik YK, Walsh BJ, Cordwell SJ |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/pmic.200300392/abstract |doi=10.1002/pmic.200300392 |pmid=12748937 |pmc= |issue=5 }} </ref>) are charged negatively in the solution, and will migrate from the [[cathode]] to the [[anode]] due to the [[electric field]]. At the anode, [[electrochemical]]ly-generated [[Hydron (chemistry)|hydrogen]] ions react with Tris molecules to form [[Monovalent ion|monovalent]] Tris ions. The positively charged Tris ions migrate through the gel to the cathode where they [[Neutralization (chemistry)|neutralise]] [[hydroxide]] ions to form Tris molecules and [[water]]. Thus, the Tris-based buffering mechanism causes a constant pH in the buffer system.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Electroanalysis |date=2006 |volume=18 |pages=103–6 |title=Comparison of the electrochemical behavior of the high molecular mass cadmium proteins in Arabidopsis thaliana and in vegetable plants on using preparative native continuous polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PNC-PAGE) |author=Kastenholz B |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/elan.200403344/abstract |doi=10.1002/elan.200403344 |pmid= |pmc= |issue=1 }} </ref> At 25 °C Tris buffer has an effective pH range between 7.5 and 9.0. Under the conditions given here (addressing the concentration, buffering mechanism, pH and temperature) the effective pH is shifted in the range of about 10.0 to 10.5. Native buffer systems all have low [[Conductivity (electrolytic)|conductivity]] and range in pH from 3.8 to 10.2. Continuous native buffer systems are used to separate proteins according their pI.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Analytical Biochemistry |year=1982 |volume=126 |pages=94–9 |title=Electrophoresis buffers for polyacrylamide gels at various pH |author=McLellan T |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0003269782901130 |doi=10.1016/0003-2697(82)90113-0 |pmid=7181120 |issue=1 }}</ref>
Although the pH value (10.00) of the electrophoresis buffer does not correspond to a [[Acid–base homeostasis|physiological pH]] value within a cell or [[biological tissue|tissue]] type, the separated ring-shaped protein bands are eluted continuously into a physiological buffer solution (pH 8.00) and isolated in different [[Fraction (chemistry)|fractions]] (see figure ''Electropherogram'').<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Nature Precedings |year=2010 |volume= |pages=1–4 |title=Isolation of acidic, basic and neutral metalloproteins by QPNC-PAGE |vauthors=Kastenholz B, Garfin DE |url=http://precedings.nature.com/documents/4617/version/1 |doi=10.1038/npre.2010.4617.1 |pmid= |issue= |origyear= |isbn=}} </ref> Provided that irreversible [[denaturation (biochemistry)|denaturation]] cannot be demonstrated (by an independent procedure), most protein molecules are stable in aqueous solution, at pH values from 3 to 10 if the temperature is below 50 °C.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Laboratory Techniques in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology |year=1969 |volume=1 |pages=34–45 |title=Electrophoresis of proteins in polyacrylamide and starch gels (Part I, Chapter 2 Acrylamide gel) |author=Gordon AH |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/bookseries/00757535/1 |doi=10.1016/S0075-7535(08)70324-3 |pmid= |issue= }}</ref> As the [[Joule heating|Joule heat]] and temperature generated during electrophoresis may exceed 50 °C,<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Electrophoresis |year=1987 |volume=8 |pages=339–45 |title=Thermal instability of electrophoresis gels |author=Woolley P |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/elps.1150080802/abstract |doi=10.1002/elps.1150080802 |pmid= |issue=8 }}</ref> and thus, have a negative impact on the stability and migration behavior of proteins, the separation system, including the electrophoresis chamber and a fraction collector, is cooled in a refrigerator at 4 °C. Overheating of the gel is impeded by internal cooling of the gel column and by generating a constant [[Power (physics)|power]] (see figure ''Equipment'').
===Gel properties and polymerization time===
Best polymerization conditions for acrylamide gels are obtained at 25-30 °C<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Electrophoresis |year=1981 |volume=2 |pages=220–28 |title=Polymerization kinetics of polyacrylamide gels II. Effect of temperature |vauthors=Gelfi C, Righetti PG |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/elps.1150020405/full |doi=10.1002/elps.1150020405 |pmid= |issue= }}</ref> and polymerization seems terminated after 20-30 min of reaction although residual [[monomer]]s (10-30%) are detected after this time.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Biochemical and Biophysical Methods |year=1979 |volume=1 |pages=105–16 |title=Estimation of polymerization efficiency in the formation of polyacrylamide gel, using continuous optical scanning during polymerization |vauthors=Chen B, Chrambach A |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0165022X79900174 |doi=10.1016/0165-022X(79)90017-4 |pmid=551105 |issue=2 }}</ref> The co-polymerization of acrylamide (AA) monomer/[[N,N'-Methylenebisacrylamide]] (Bis-AA) cross-linker initiated by [[ammonium persulfate]] (APS)/[[tetramethylethylenediamine]] (TEMED) reactions, is most efficient at alkaline pH. Thereby, acrylamide chains are created and cross-linked at a time. Due to the properties of the electrophoresis buffer the gel polymerization is conducted at pH 10.00 making sure an efficient use of TEMED and APS as [[catalyst]]s of the polymerization reaction, and concurrently, suppressing a competitive [[hydrolysis]] of the produced acrylamide [[polymer]] network (cf. section ''Principle''). Otherwise, proteins could be modified by reaction with unpolymerized monomers of acrylamide, forming [[Covalent bond|covalent]] acrylamide [[adduct]]ion products that may result in multiple bands.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Analytical Biochemistry |year=1994 |volume=222 |pages=44–8 |title=Acrylamide in polyacrylamide gels can modify proteins during electrophoresis |vauthors=Bonaventura C, Bonaventura J, Stevens R, Millington D |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003269784714515 |doi=10.1006/abio.1994.1451 |pmid=7856869 |issue=1 }}</ref>
Additionally, the time of polymerization of a gel may directly affect the peak-elution times of separated metalloproteins in the [[Electrophoretogram|electropherogram]] due to the compression and dilatation of the gels and their pores with the longer incubation times (see figure ''Electropherogram'', cf. subsection ''Reproducibility and recovery''). In order to ensure maximum reproducibility in gel pore size and to obtain a fully polymerized and non-restrictive large pore gel for a PAGE run, the [[polyacrylamide gel]] is polymerized for a time period of 69 hr at [[room temperature]] (RT). The [[Exothermic reaction|exothermic]] heat generated by the polymerization processes is [[Dissipation|dissipated]] constantly while the temperature may rise rapidly to over 75 °C in the first minutes, after which it falls slowly.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Biotechnology and Bioengineering |year=1983 |volume=25 |pages=623–6 |title=Temperature effects during polymerization of polyacrylamide gels used for bacterial cell immobilization |vauthors=Wheatley MA, Phillips CR |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/bit.260250228/full |doi=10.1002/bit.260250228 |pmid=18548679 |issue=2 }}</ref> After 69 hr the gel has reached room temperature, and thus, is in its lowest [[Internal energy|energy]] state because the chemical reactions and the gelation are terminated. Gelation means that the solvent (water) gets immobilized within the polymer network by means of [[hydrogen bond]]s and also [[van der Waals force]]s. As a result, the prepared gel is [[Homogeneity (physics)|homogeneous]] (in terms of homogeneous distribution of [[cross-links]] throughout the gel sample<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Polymer |year=2003 |volume=44 |pages=5239–50 |title=Effect of hydrolysis on spatial inhomogeneity in poly(acrylamide) gels of various crosslink densities |vauthors=Kizilay MY, Okay O |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0032386103004944 |doi=10.1016/S0032-3861(03)00494-4 |pmid= |issue=18 }}</ref>), inherently stable and free of monomers or [[radical (chemistry)|radicals]]. Fresh polyacrylamide gels are further [[hydrophile|hydrophilic]], electrically neutral and do not bind proteins.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Expert Review of Proteomics |year=2009 |volume=6 |pages=239–41 |title=25th Annual Meeting of the American Electrophoresis Society |author=Garfin DE |url=http://informahealthcare.com/doi/pdf/10.1586/epr.09.18 |doi=10.1586/epr.09.18 |pmid=19489696 |issue=3 }}</ref> Sieving effects due to [[gravity]]-induced [[Compression (physics)|compression]] of the gel can be excluded for the same reasons. In a medium without molecular sieving properties a high-resolution can be expected.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Chromatography A |year=1963 |volume=11 |pages=66–70 |title="Molecular-sieve" electrophoresis in cross-linked polyacrylamide gels |author=Hjertén S |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021967301808700 |doi=10.1016/S0021-9673(01)80870-0 |pmid= |issue= }}</ref>
Before an electrophoretic run is started the prepared 4% T (total polymer content (T)), 2.67% C (cross-linker concentration (C)) gel is pre-run to equilibrate it. It is essentially non-sieving and optimal for electrophoresis of proteins greater than or equal to 200 k[[atomic mass unit|u]] (cf. [[agarose gel electrophoresis]]). Proteins migrate in it more or less on the basis of their free mobility.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Methods in Enzymology |year=2009 |volume=463 |pages=497–513 |title=Chapter 29 one-dimensional gel electrophoresis |author=Garfin DE |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0076687909630299 |doi=10.1016/S0076-6879(09)63029-9 |pmid=19892189 |issue= |origyear=1990 |isbn=978-0-12-374536-1}} </ref> For these reasons [[Chemical interaction|interaction]]s of the gel with the biomolecules are negligibly low, and thus, the proteins separate cleanly and predictably at a polymerization time of 69 hr (see figure ''Electropherogram''). The separated metalloproteins including biomolecules ranging from approximately < 1 ku to greater than 30 ku (e.g., metal [[chaperone (protein)|chaperone]]s, [[prion]]s, metal transport proteins, [[amyloid]]s, metalloenzymes, metallo[[peptides]], [[metallothionein]], [[phytochelatin]]s) are not dissociated into [[Apoenzyme#Cofactors|apoprotein]]s and metal cofactors.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Analytical Letters |issn= |year=2008 |volume=41 |pages=1773–84 |title=Molybdenum speciation in raw phloem sap of castor bean |vauthors=Fitri N, Kastenholz B, Buchari B, Amran MB, Warganegara FM |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00032710802162442#.VesDkT_osy8 |doi=10.1080/00032710802162442 |issue=10 }}</ref>
===Reproducibility and recovery===
[[File:Preparative Electroph.TIF|thumb|315px|''Electropherogram'' showing four PAGE runs of a native [[Size-exclusion chromatography|chromatographically]] prepurified high molecular weight cadmium protein (≈ 200 ku) as a [[Function (mathematics)|function]] of time of polymerization of the gel (4% T, 2.67% C). Detection method for Cd cofactors (in µg/L): [[Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption|GF-AAS]]]] The bioactive structures (native or [[Three-dimensional space|3D]] conformation or shape) of the isolated protein molecules do not undergo any significant [[conformational change]]s. Thus, active metal cofactor-containing proteins can be isolated reproducibly in the same fractions after a PAGE run (see figure ''Electropherogram''). A shifting peak in the respective electropherogram may indicate that the standardized time of gel polymerization (69 hr, RT) is not implemented in a PAGE [[experiment]]. A lower deviation of the standardized polymerization time (< 69 hr) stands for incomplete polymerization, and thus, for inherent instability due to gel softening during the cross-linking of polymers as the material reaches swelling equilibrium,<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Biotechniques |year=2005 |volume=39 |pages=847–51 |title=Bulk and micropatterned conjugation of extracellular matrix proteins to characterized polyacrylamide substrates for cell mechanotransduction assays |vauthors=Damljanović V, Lagerholm BC, Jacobson K |url=http://www.biotechniques.com/BiotechniquesJournal/2005/December/Bulk-and-micropatterned-conjugation-of-extracellular-matrix-proteins-to-characterized-polyacrylamide-substrates-for-cell-mechanotransduction-assays/biotechniques-45617.html?autnID=237360 |doi=10.2144/000112026 |pmid=16382902 |issue=6 }} </ref> whereas exceeding this time limit (> 69 hr) is an indicator of gel aging.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Polymer Bulletin |year=1980 |volume=3 |pages=621–5 |title=Collapse of polyacrylamide gels |vauthors=Stejskal J, Gordon M, Torkington JA |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01135333 |doi=10.1007/BF01135333 |pmid= |issue=11 }} </ref> The phenomenon of gel aging is closely connected to long-term [[viscosity]] decrease of aqueous polyacrylamide solutions<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Progress in Polymer Science |year=1982 |volume=8 |pages=373–468 |title=Preparation, characterization, solution properties and rheological behaviour of polyacrylamide |vauthors=Kulicke WM, Kniewske R, Klein J |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0079670082900041 |doi=10.1016/0079-6700(82)90004-1 |pmid= |issue=4 }} </ref> and increased swelling of hydrogels.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Soft Matter |year=2010 |volume=6 |pages=6004–12 |title=Poroelastic swelling kinetics of thin hydrogel layers: comparison of theory and experiment |vauthors=Yoon J, Cai S, Suo Z, Hayward RC |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2010/sm/c0sm00434k#!divAbstract |doi=10.1039/C0SM00434K |pmid= |issue= |bibcode=2010SMat....6.6004Y}} </ref> The electroelution and subsequent detection of the analysed protein is not reproducible due to sieving effects (see figures ''Electropherogram'' and ''Hydrolysis'', cf. section ''Principle'').
Under standard conditions (69 hr), metalloproteins with different molecular mass ranges and isoelectric points have been recovered in biologically active form at a quantitative yield of more than 95%.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Protein and Peptide Letters |year=2006 |volume=13 |pages=503–8 |title=Important contributions of a new quantitative preparative native continuous polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (QPNC-PAGE) procedure for elucidating metal cofactor metabolisms in protein-misfolding diseases – a theory |author=Kastenholz B |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/ppl/2006/00000013/00000005/art00015 |doi=10.2174/092986606776819637 |pmid=16800806 |issue=5 }} </ref> By preparative [[Sodium dodecyl sulfate|SDS]] [[polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis]] standard proteins ([[cytochrome c]], [[aldolase]], [[ovalbumin]] and [[bovine serum albumin]]) with molecular masses of 14-66 ku can be recovered with an average yield of about 73,6%.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Chromatography |year=1991 |volume=585 |pages=153–9 |title=Preparative high-yield electroelution of proteins after separation by sodium dodecyl sulphate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and its application to analysis of amino acid sequences and to raise antibodies |vauthors=Ohhashi T, Moritani C, Andoh H, Satoh S, Ohmori S, Lottspeich F, Ikeda M |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/00219673/585/1 |doi=10.1016/0021-9673(91)85069-r |pmid=1666109 |issue=1 }} </ref> Preparative [[isotachophoresis]] (ITP) is applied for isolating [[palladium]]-containing proteins with molecular masses of 362 ku (recovery: 67%) and 158 ku (recovery: 97%).<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Electrophoresis |year=2004 |volume=25 |pages=1758–64 |title=Improved separation of palladium species in biological matrices by using a combination of gel permeation chromatography and isotachophoresis |vauthors=Weber G, Messerschmidt J, von Bohlen A, Kastenholz B, Günther K |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/elps.200305833/abstract |doi=10.1002/elps.200305833 |pmid=15213973 |issue=12 }} </ref>
===Quantification and identification===
Physiological concentrations ([[Parts per billion|ppb]]-range) of Fe, Cu, Zn, [[nickel|Ni]], [[molybdenum|Mo]], Pd, [[copper|Co]], [[manganese|Mn]], [[platinum|Pt]], [[chromium|Cr]], [[cadmium|Cd]] and other metal cofactors can be identified and absolutely quantified in an [[Sample (material)|aliquot]] of a fraction by [[inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry]] (ICP-MS)<ref>Rašovský P (2011). [http://is.muni.cz/th/222702/prif_m/?furl=%2Fth%2F222702%2Fprif_m%2F;so=nx;lang=en "Utilisation of column gel eletrophoresis for on-line connection to ICP-MS for metalloproteomics"]. Archive of Thesis, Masaryk University, Brno.</ref> or total reflection [[X-ray fluorescence]] (TXRF),<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Spectrochimica Acta Part B Atomic Spectroscopy |year=2010 |volume=65 |pages=504–7 |title=Quantitative determination on heavy metals in different stages of wine production by total reflection X-ray fluorescence and energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence: comparison on two vineyards |vauthors=Pessanha S, Carvalho ML, Becker M, von Bohlen A |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S058485471000114X |doi=10.1016/j.sab.2010.04.003 |pmid= |issue=6 |bibcode=2010AcSpe..65..504P }}</ref> for example. In case of ICP-MS the structural information of the associated metallobiomolecules<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Analytical Atomic Spectrometry |year=2004 |volume=19 |pages=1–4 |title=Metallobiomolecules. The basis of life, the challenge of atomic spectroscopy |vauthors=Jakubowski N, Lobinski R, Moens L |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlehtml/2004/ja/b313299b |doi=10.1039/B313299B |pmid= |issue=1 }}</ref> is irreversibly lost due to [[ionization]] of the sample with [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]].<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Chemical Society Reviews |year=2009 |volume=38 |pages=1119–38 |title=Metallomics: the concept and methodology |vauthors=Mounicou S, Szpunar J, Lobinski R |url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2009/cs/b713633c#!divAbstract |doi= 10.1039/B713633C |pmid=19421584 |issue=4 }}</ref> Another established high sensitive detection method for the determination of (trace) [[Chemical element|elements]] is graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrometry (GF-AAS) (see figure ''Electropherogram'').<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Analytical Chemistry |year=2001 |volume=73 |pages=4319–25 |title=Direct and simultaneous determination of copper, chromium, aluminum, and manganese in urine with a multielement graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrometer |vauthors=Lin TW, Huang SD |url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ac010319h |doi=10.1021/ac010319h |pmid=11569826 |issue=17 }}</ref> Because of high purity and optimized [[concentration]] of the separated metalloproteins, for example, therapeutic recombinant [[pharming (genetics)|plant-made pharmaceuticals]] such as [[CCS (gene)|copper chaperone for superoxide dismutase]] (CCS) from [[medicinal plants]], in a few specific PAGE fractions, the related structures of these [[analyte]]s can be elucidated quantitatively by using [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy of proteins|solution]] [[NMR spectroscopy]] under non-denaturing conditions.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Protein and Peptide Letters |year=2009 |volume=16 |pages=116–20 |title=Medicinal plants: a natural chaperones source for treating neurological disorders |vauthors=Kastenholz B, Garfin DE |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/ppl/2009/00000016/00000002/art00003 |doi=10.2174/092986609787316234 |pmid=19200033 |issue=2 }}</ref>
==Applications==
Improperly folded metal proteins, for example, CCS or [[SOD1|Cu/Zn-superoxide dismutase]] (SOD1) present in [[brain]], [[blood]] or other clinical samples, are indicative of [[neurodegenerative diseases]] like Alzheimer's disease (AD) or [[Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis]] (ALS).<ref>{{cite journal |journal=European Journal of Clinical Nutrition |year=2002 |volume=56 |pages=469–83 |title=Hohenheim consensus workshop: copper |vauthors=Schümann K, Classen HG, Dieter HH, König J, Multhaup G, Rükgauer M, Summer KH, Bernhardt J, Biesalski HK |url=http://www.nature.com/ejcn/journal/v56/n6/full/1601315a.html |doi=10.1038/sj.ejcn.1601315 |pmid=12032645 |issue=6 }}</ref> Active CCS or SOD molecules contribute to intracellular [[homeostasis|homeostatic]] control of essential metal ions (e.g., [[copper in health|Cu<sup>1+/2+</sup>]], Zn<sup>2+</sup>, Fe<sup>2+/3+</sup>, Mn<sup>2+</sup>, Ni<sup>3+</sup>) in organisms, and thus, these biomolecules can balance pro-[[Redox|oxidative]] and antioxidative processes in the [[cytoplasm]]. Otherwise, free (loosely bound) transition metal ions take part in [[Fenton's reagent|Fenton-like reactions]] in which deleterious [[hydroxyl radical]] is formed, which unrestrained would be destructive to proteins.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Annual Review of Biochemistry |year=2010 |volume=79 |pages=537–62 |title=Copper metallochaperones |vauthors=Robinson NJ, Winge DR |url=http://www.annualreviews.org/eprint/nBShYjmeQPGIIM2RQ8pk/full/10.1146/annurev-biochem-030409-143539 |doi=10.1146/annurev-biochem-030409-143539 |pmid=20205585 |issue= |pmc=3986808 }}</ref> The loss of (active) CCS increases the [[Amyloid beta|amyloid-β]] production in [[neuron]]s which, in turn, is a major pathological hallmark of AD.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Alzheimer's Disease |year=2010 |volume=21 |pages=1101–5 |title=Deficiency of the copper chaperone for superoxide dismutase increases amyloid-β production |vauthors=Gray EH, De Vos KJ, Dingwall C, Perkinton MS, Miller CC |url=https://kclpure.kcl.ac.uk/portal/en/publications/deficiency-of-the-copper-chaperone-for-superoxide-dismutase-increases-amyloidbeta-production%28c77f8680-3cdb-4426-a654-d3fc47c5320c%29.html |doi=10.3233/JAD-2010-100717 |pmid=20693630 |issue=4 |pmc=3023902 }}</ref> Therefore, copper chaperone for superoxide dismutase is proposed to be one of the most promising [[biomarker]]s of Cu [[toxicity]] in these diseases.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Neurotoxicology |year=2014 |volume=40 |pages=97–101 |title=Copper toxicity induced hepatocerebral and neurodegenerative diseases: an urgent need for prognostic biomarkers |author=Pal A |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0161813X13001824 |doi=10.1016/j.neuro.2013.12.001 |pmid=24342654 |issue= }}</ref> CCS should be analysed primarily in blood because a [[meta-analysis]] of [[Serum (blood)|serum]] data showed that AD patients have higher levels of serum Cu than healthy controls.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Alzheimer's Disease |year=2011 |volume=24 |pages=175–85 |title=Copper in Alzheimer's disease: a meta-analysis of serum, plasma, and cerebrospinal fluid studies |vauthors=Bucossi S, Ventriglia M, Panetta V, Salustri C, Pasqualetti P, Mariani S, Siotto M, Rossini PM, Squitti R |doi=10.3233/JAD-2010-101473 |pmid=21187586 |issue=1 }}</ref>
==Principle==
===History===
[[File:PAAG.tif|thumb|''Hydrolysis'' of a polymeric network structure at basic pH: the [[carboxamide]] groups react with H<sub>2</sub>O leaving ionized [[Carboxylic acid|carboxyls]]. The modified acrylamide gels swell as they suck up buffer ions and water to neutralize the carboxyls. Thus, the gel properties are changed.]]In the 20th century it was generally accepted that APS/TEMED-initiated reactions should be allowed to proceed for 5-15 min<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Science |year=1971 |volume=172 |pages=440–51 |title=Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis |vauthors=Chrambach A, Rodbard D |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/172/3982/440.abstract?sid=d82e164d-930d-47d3-9683-bf7088913175 |doi=10.1126/science.172.3982.440 |pmid=4927678 |issue=3982 |bibcode=1971Sci...172..440C }}</ref> to approx. 30 min<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Nature Protocols |year=2006 |volume=1 |pages=418–28 |title=Blue native PAGE |vauthors=Wittig I, Braun HP, Schägger H |url=http://www.nature.com/nprot/journal/v1/n1/full/nprot.2006.62.html |doi=10.1038/nprot.2006.62 |pmid=17406264 |issue=1 }}</ref> to ensure maximum reproducibility in gel pore size of PAGE gels. In another review it is recommended to allow the gel to polymerize overnight at room temperature.<ref>{{cite journal |journal= Methods in Molecular Biology |year=2012 |volume=869 |pages=633–40 |title=Common artifacts and mistakes made in electrophoresis |vauthors=Kurien BT, Scofield RH |url=https://link.springer.com/protocol/10.1007%2F978-1-61779-821-4_58 |doi=10.1007/978-1-61779-821-4_58 |pmid=22585529 |issue= }}</ref> Longer incubation times (16 hr to 2 wk) to finish the three-dimensional matrix (network) formation might not have any essential effects on the protein separation process.<ref>Kozulic B (1995). [http://worldwide.espacenet.com/publicationDetails/biblio?FT=D&date=19951017&DB=EPODOC&locale=en_EP&CC=US&NR=5458760A&KC=A&ND=7 "Gel composition in gels for submurged gel electrophoresis"]. Patent US5458760 (A).</ref> Westermeier annotates that due to silent polymerization the gels might be placed in a refrigerator shortly after (visible) polymerization.<ref>{{cite book |publisher=Wiley |year=2016 |isbn=9783527338801 |title=Electrophoresis in practice: a guide to methods and applications of DNA and protein separations, fifth edition |author=Westermeier R |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/book/10.1002/9783527695188 |doi=10.1002/9783527695188 |pmid= |issue= }} </ref> In the cold room, however, the (exothermic) reaction is not completed within a reasonable period of time. In a technical note ("Acrylamide Polymerization - A Practical Approach") [[Bio-Rad Laboratories|Bio-Rad]] claims that polymerization may be largely complete after about 90 min at room temperature.
Now here is the question to answer: Is there only an approximate polymerization time in the range of minutes to hours, or is there reliable experimental data indicating the general validity of a polymerization time for any PAGE gels?
Progressively hydrolyzing into [[polyacrylic acid]] and [[ammonia]] polyacrylamide gels were further considered as inherently unstable with respect to polymer resistance to alkaline media (see figure ''Hydrolysis''). However, this hypothesis cannot be generalized. As acrylamide starts to hydrolyze at pH around 10<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Biochemical and Biophysical Methods |year=1989 |volume=19 |pages=21–36 |title=Polyacrylamide derivatives to the service of bioseparations |author=Boschetti E |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0165022X89900481 |doi=10.1016/0165-022X(89)90048-1 |pmid=2809065 |issue=1 }}</ref> the hydrolysis rate of aqueous solutions of polyacrylamide is at a maximum at pH 4, and at a minimum at pH 10.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Russian Journal of Applied Chemistry |year=2001 |volume=74 |pages=543–54 |title=Alkaline hydrolysis of polyacrylamide |vauthors=Kurenkov VF, Hartan H, Lobanov FI |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1012786826774 |doi=10.1023/A:1012786826774 |pmid= |issue=4 }}</ref> Slow hydrolytic processes of fresh gels (pH 10.00) polymerized for 69 hr do not affect the peak-elution times of proteins in the electropherogram (see figure ''Electropherogram''). Upon physiological conditions (pH 8.00) and after overnight polymerization, however, only semi-quantitative analysis of low amounts of the cofactor of interest could be performed by native PAGE using GF-AAS as detection method.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Fresenius' Journal of Analytical Chemistry |year=2000 |volume=368 |pages=281–7 |title=Characterization of high molecular weight cadmium species in contaminated vegetable food |vauthors=Günther K, Ji G, Kastenholz B |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s002160000431 |doi=10.1007/s002160000431 |pmid=11220593 |issue=2 }}</ref> Therefore, the relationship between the polymerization time, gel stability (incomplete polymerization, hydrolysis), pH and analytical results had to be investigated addressing the absolute quantification of specific protein molecules:
In 2001 a new basic principle of gel electrophoresis was discovered at the [[Forschungszentrum Jülich]], applied for [[patent]] in 2003 and subsequently issued in 2014.<ref>Kastenholz B (2014) [2003]. [http://worldwide.espacenet.com/publicationDetails/biblio?DB=EPODOC&II=1&ND=3&adjacent=true&locale=en_EP&FT=D&date=20050217&CC=WO&NR=2005014147A2&KC=A2 "Method for isolating metal cofactors out from biologically-organic systems involving the use of preparative native continuous polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PNC-PAGE)"]. Patent WO2005014147 (A2).</ref> This invention provided the first conclusive evidence that the time of polymerization of a polyacrylamide gel directly affects the result of [[protein purification]] because the separation properties implying the mechanical and [[chemical stability]] of a gel and its pores are determined by this parameter. As a consequence, the peak-elution times of the separated metalloproteins in the electropherogram may vary considerably (see figure ''Electropherogram''). On the other hand, the results of [[protein electrophoresis]] can be optimized in terms of reliability by strict adherence to a standardized time of polymerization (69 hr). This optimization process of selected electrophoretic parameters paved the way to "quantitative native PAGE" implying high reproducibility in gel pore size and high-yield electroelution of proteins in biological samples.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Analytical Letters |year=2004 |volume=37 |pages=657–65 |title=Preparative native continuous polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PNC‐PAGE): an efficient method for isolating cadmium cofactors in biological systems |author=Kastenholz B |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1081/AL-120029742#.VerDcj_osy8 |doi=10.1081/AL-120029742 |pmid= |issue=4 }}</ref>
Although the quality, quantity and mixing ratio of TEMED, APS and AA/Bis-AA as well as the ambient temperature are the most important factors to initiate and impel the polymerization reaction of PAGE gels, it is evident that the time of polymerization is the limiting factor in these [[Physical chemistry|physico-chemical]] processes to form an inherently stable network of polymers.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Progress in Colloid and Polymer Science Vol 136: Gels: Structures, Properties, and Functions |year=2009 |volume= |pages=87–94 |title=Some thoughts on the definition of a gel |author=Nishinari K |url=https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-642-00865-8 |doi= |pmid= |issue= |isbn=9783642008641 }}</ref> Systematic investigations of the hydrogel stability over time reveal significant changes in gel structure ([[porosity]]) by day 3 (72 hr) after (visible) polymerization of 10% T, 15% T, and 20% T gels (under acidic conditions).<ref>{{cite journal |journal=ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces |year=2016 |volume=8 |pages=21893–902 |title=Tuning the range of polyacrylamide gel stiffness for mechanobiology applications |vauthors=Denisin AK, Pruitt BL |url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsami.5b09344 |doi=10.1021/acsami.5b09344 |pmid=26816386 |issue=34 |isbn= }}</ref> This study is supported by another systematic investigation on gel aging, indicating that low concentrations of carboxyls are detectable after 3 days of acrylamide polymerization.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Macromolecules |year=1984 |volume=17 |pages=2868–74 |title=Phase transition in swollen gels. 6. Effect of aging on the extent of hydrolysis of aqueous polyacrylamide solutions and on the collapse of gels |vauthors=Ilavsky M, Hrouz J, Stejskal J, Bouchal K |url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021%2Fma00142a072 |doi=10.1021/ma00142a072 |pmid= |issue=12 |isbn= |bibcode=1984MaMol..17.2868I}}</ref>
These results are in excellent agreement with that the aging of fresh polyacrylamide gels begins after 69 hr cross-linking and gelation time bringing a shift of the peak-elution times of proteins due to gel swelling induced by hydrolysis of carboxamide groups into carboxylate anions (see figures ''Electropherogram'' and ''Hydrolysis''). Thus, the polymerization time of 69 hr is a pH-independent stability constant in the pH range of about 4 (acrylamide/[[aqueous solution]]) to 10 (acrylamide/buffer solution) for acrylamide gels with total monomer concentrations in the range of 4 to 20% T.
===Persons===
[[File:Awards Talk 1.jpg|thumb|Awards Talk 1|275px|''David Garfin'' at the start of his historic talk presenting his ''Reminiscences About Electrophoresis'' on the occasion of the 2013 AES Electrophoresis Society Awards Session in San Francisco]] First publications from 2007/2009 concerning the [[medicine|medical]] applications of this technique were edited or co-authored by the [[Münster]]an [[human genetics|human geneticist]] Prof. em. Jürgen Horst and the well-known [[Americans|American]] [[scientist]] and internationally recognized expert in the fields of [[DNA]] [[sequence analysis]] and protein electrophoresis David E. Garfin (see figure ''David Garfin''). Beginning in the late 1960s D.E.G. used paper electrophoresis to sequence [[oligonucleotide]]s prepared from [[tobacco mosaic virus]] [[ribonucleic acid]].<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Virology |year=1975 |volume=64 |pages=388–99 |title=Sequences of oligonucleotides prepared from tobacco mosaic virus ribonucleic acid |vauthors=Garfin DE, Mandeles S |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0042682275901154 |doi=10.1016/0042-6822(75)90115-4 |pmid=166485 |issue=2 }}</ref> In the 1970s and the early 1980s Dr. Garfin became one of the most important investigators and early pioneers in the field of prion research ([[scrapie]]) in the team of the later [[Nobel Prize]] winner [[Stanley B. Prusiner]] at the [[University of California, San Francisco|UCSF]].<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Journal of Neurochemistry |year=1980 |volume=35 |pages=574–82 |title=Experimental scrapie in the mouse: electrophoretic and sedimentation properties of the partially purified agent |vauthors=Prusiner SB, Garfin DE, Cochran SP, McKinley MP, Groth DF, Hadlow WJ, Race RE, Eklund CM |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1471-4159.1980.tb03693.x/abstract;jsessionid=F43CC9E08DDF1B87DE57CE0B9D93AE38.f01t04?deniedAccessCustomisedMessage=&userIsAuthenticated=false |doi=10.1111/j.1471-4159.1980.tb03693.x |pmid=6778963 |issue=3 }}</ref>
In addition to his pioneering work on one- and [[two-dimensional gel electrophoresis]] in the following decades at Bio-Rad Laboratories as Proteomics Applications Manager<ref>{{cite journal |journal=TrAC Trends in Analytical Chemistry |year=2003 |volume=22 |pages=263–72 |title=Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis: an overview |author=Garfin DE |url=http://www.bio-rad.com/LifeScience/pdf/Two-dimensionalGel.pdf |doi=10.1016/S0165-9936(03)00506-5 |pmid= |issue=5 }}</ref> he became co-editor of the ''Handbook of Isoelectric Focusing and Proteomics'' (2005)<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Separation Science and Technology |date=2005 |volume=7 |pages=1–334 |title=Handbook of Isoelectric Focusing and Proteomics |vauthors=Garfin DE, Ahuja S |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/bookseries/18771718/7 |doi= |pmid= |pmc= |isbn=978-0-12-088752-1 |issue= }} </ref> and co-authored a worth reading chapter on bioseparation methods in the ''Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology'' (2007).<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology |year=2007 |volume= |pages=1–49 |title=Bioseparations, separation methods in proteomics |vauthors=Garfin DE, Ahuja S |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/0471238961.biosahuj.a01/abstract |doi=10.1002/0471238961.biosahuj.a01 |pmid= |issue= }}</ref> Furthermore, Garfin is author of several breakthrough articles, some of which are cited here and which may substantially complement and confirm the method presented here. For significant contributions to [[History of electrophoresis|electrophoresis]] in both the [[engineering]] and biology communities Dave Garfin received the 2013 AES Electrophoresis Society Career Award in [[San Francisco]] (see figure ''David Garfin'').<ref>Fintschenko Y, Salmanzadeh A, Davalos R (2014).[http://www.americanlaboratory.com/166335-AES-2013-Annual-Meeting-of-the-AES-Electrophoresis-Society/ "AES 2013: Annual Meeting of the AES Electrophoresis Society"]. ''American Laboratory''.</ref>
===Biomedicine===
Garfin, Horst, Nagel and other researchers from the Forschungszentrum Jülich anticipated that the above-mentioned approach might be implemented in the therapy and diagnosis of several protein-misfolding diseases: on the one hand, copper chaperone for superoxide dismutase may serve as a fluid-based biomarker for Cu toxicity in neurodegenerative diseases (cf. section ''Applications''), on the other hand, copper chaperones,<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Biochemistry (Moscow) |year=2003 |volume=68 |pages=827–37 |title=Copper chaperones, intracellular copper trafficking proteins. Function, structure, and mechanism of action |vauthors=Markossian KA, Kurganov BI |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023%2FA%3A1025740228888 |doi=10.1023/A:1025740228888 |pmid=12948382 |issue=8 }}</ref> and smaller non protein-bound metal [[Chemical species|species]] (e.g., Cu [[Orotic acid|orotate]],<ref>{{cite journal |journal=International Journal of Alzheimer's Disease |year=2011 |volume=2011 |pages=1–5 |title=Disturbed copper bioavailability in Alzheimer's Disease |vauthors=Kaden D, Bush AI, Danzeisen R, Bayer TA, Multhaup G |url=http://www.hindawi.com/journals/ijad/2011/345614/ |doi=10.4061/2011/345614 |pmid=22145082 |issue= |pmc=3227474 }}</ref> [[Lithium chloride|Li chloride]]<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Nature |year=2003 |volume=423 |pages=435–9 |title=GSK-3α regulates production of Alzheimer's disease amyloid-β peptides |vauthors=Phiel CJ, Wilson CA, Lee VM, Klein PS |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v423/n6938/full/nature01640.html |doi=10.1038/nature01640 |pmid=12761548 |issue=6938 |bibcode=2003Natur.423..435P }}</ref>) are indicated as [[lead compounds]] for the etiological treatment of Alzheimer's disease.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Amyloid |year=2009 |volume=16 |pages=81–3 |title=Plant metal chaperones: a novel perspective in dementia therapy |vauthors=Kastenholz B, Garfin DE, Horst J, Nagel KA |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13506120902879392?journalCode=iamy20 |doi=10.1080/13506120902879392 |pmid=20536399 |issue=2 }}</ref>
According to the [[Hofmeister series]] [[salt]] [[Efficacy|effects]] could be one approach for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease by using certain salts for dissolving [[Protein aggregation|protein aggregates]] or inhibiting amyloid formation.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Protein Science |year=2009 |volume=19 |pages=47–56 |title=The Hofmeister effect on amyloid formation using yeast prion protein |vauthors=Yeh V, Broering JM, Romanyuk A, Chen B, Chernoff YO, Bommarius AS |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/pro.281/abstract |doi=10.1002/pro.281 |pmid=19890987 |issue=1 |pmc=2817838}} </ref> Adding salts to complex protein mixtures, however, may induce a shift of isoelectric points, and thus, affect protein structure (shape) and activity. In this context, one study found that [[kosmotropic]] salts (e.g., [[ammonium sulfate]]) that were used for the [[Protein precipitation|precipitation]] of native proteins in solution, subsequently, may result in denatured high molecular weight metalloproteins in the same solution.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Protein and Peptide Letters |year=2007 |volume=14 |pages=389–93 |title=New hope for the diagnosis and therapy of Alzheimer's disease |author=Kastenholz B |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/ppl/2007/00000014/00000004/art00012?crawler=true |doi=10.2174/092986607780363970 |pmid=17504097 |issue=4 }} </ref> Ions which promote aggregation or [[Fractionation|prefractionation]] in proteome analysis, simultaneously cause denaturation of the native conformation of the proteins of interest. In opposite case [[Chaotropic agent|chaotropic salts]] force globular proteins to unfold.<ref>{{cite book |publisher=Wiley |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-470-41196-4 |title=Aggregation of therapeutic proteins |vauthors=Wang W, Roberts CJ |url=http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470411961.html |doi= |pmid= |issue= }} </ref> For these reasons, restoring the physiological state of aggregated and/or unfolded (metal) proteins by applying Hofmeister salts in the therapy of Alzheimer's disease is very unlikely to happen. For example, Li chloride caused a reduction in [[Protein biosynthesis|protein synthesis]] and hence, the level of amyloid-β peptides, however, this compound may also generate severe [[side effect]]s induced by long-term, high-dose [[Lithium (medication)|lithium]].<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Frontiers in Aging Neuroscience |year=2014 |volume=6 |pages=190 |title=Lithium suppresses Aβ pathology by inhibiting translation in an adult Drosophila model of Alzheimer's disease |vauthors=Sofola-Adesakin O, Castillo-Quan JI, Rallis C, Tain LS, Bjedov I, Rogers I, Li L, Martinez P, Khericha M, Cabecinha M, Bähler J, Partridge L |url=http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fnagi.2014.00190/abstract |doi=10.3389/fnagi.2014.00190 |pmid= |issue= }} </ref>
[[Curcumin]] is one of the most promising therapeutic agents for [[inflammation]], [[cystic fibrosis]], Alzheimer's disease and [[cancer]] because these biomolecules scavenge radicals and maintain the levels of (active) antioxidant enzymes (e.g., SOD1)<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Clinical Biochemistry |year=1999 |volume=32 |pages=595–603 |title=Antioxidant enzymes and human diseases |vauthors=Matés JM, Pérez-Gómez C, Núñez de Castro I |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0009912099000752 |doi=10.1016/S0009-9120(99)00075-2 |pmid=10638941 |issue=8 }} </ref> in the presence of copper. Curcumin is almost free from side effects, however, limited for application due to its poor bioavailability.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Current Pharmaceutical Design |year=2013 |volume=19 |pages=2070–83 |title=Delivery of curcumin and medicinal effects of the copper(II)-curcumin complexes |vauthors=Leung MH, Harada T, Kee TW |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/cpd/2013/00000019/00000011/art00008?crawler=true |doi=10.2174/138161213805289237 |pmid=23116313 |issue=11 }} </ref> Transgenic plants grown on plant phenotyping platforms to be used for [[high-throughput screening]] analysis of [[shoot]] and [[root]], may help to provide [[biopharmaceuticals|bioactive therapeutic (metal) proteins]] as a major basis for pharmacological efficiency (non-toxic, high specificity, well known [[mechanisms of action]]) and bioeconomy approaches in conformational diseases.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Protein and Peptide Letters |year=2010 |volume=17 |pages=723–31 |title=Novel detection system for plant protein production of pharmaceuticals and impact on conformational diseases |vauthors=Nagel KA, Kastenholz B, Gilmer F, Schurr U, Walter A |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/ppl/2010/00000017/00000006/art00006 |doi=10.2174/092986610791190282 |pmid=20015023 |issue=6 }} </ref>
