revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Military research facilities to [[:Category:Military research installations]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 June 4]].
revision.text:
The '''SHAPE Technical Centre''' or [[Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe]] Technical Centre (STC) was formerly known as the SHAPE Air Defence Technical Centre (SADTC). It was formed in 1955 and located in [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]]. It conducted research and development for NATO in the area of air defence, in support of NATO funded procurements and interoperability. In 1996 it was merged with [[NACISA]] to form [[NC3A]].
== See also == * [[Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe]] * [[NC3A]] * [[NACISA]] * [[T. William Olle]]
== External links == * [http://www.nc3a.nato.int NC3A official web site]
{{int-org-stub}} [[Category:NATO agencies]] [[Category:Military research installations]] [[Category:1955 establishments in the Netherlands]]

revision.comment: minor copy edits, condensed refs, trimmed some redundant wording
revision.text:
{{infobox company | name = Science Week logo | logo = [[Image:Science_Week_Ireland_Logo.jpg]] }}
'''Science Week Ireland''' is an annual week-long event in Ireland each November, celebrating [[science]] in our everyday lives. Science Week is an initiative of Science Foundation Ireland (SFI)<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ahlstrom|first1=Dick|title=Science Week offers parents a look at alternative paths for students|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/innovation/science-week-offers-parents-a-look-at-alternative-paths-for-students-1.3292760|website=The Irish Times Online|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> It is the largest science festival in the country, engaging tens of thousands of members of the general public in workshops, science shows, talks, laboratory demonstrations, science walks and other science-related events.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Foundation Ireland Events|url=http://www.sfi.ie/events/|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref> Science Week is a collaboration of events involving industry, colleges, schools, libraries, teachers, researchers and students throughout Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|title=Key objective of Science Week is to inspire young people to take up careers in area|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/science/key-objective-of-science-week-is-to-inspire-young-people-to-take-up-careers-in-area-1.1971458|website=Irish Times Online|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
Science Week supports Science Foundation Ireland’s mission to catalyse, inspire and guide the best in science, technology, engineering and maths (STEM) education and public engagement.<ref>{{cite web|title=SFI Discover Funding Programme|url=http://www.sfi.ie/engagement/sfi-discover/|website=sfi.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> The ultimate aim of this effort is that Ireland will have the most engaged and scientifically informed public by 2020 as outlined in Science Foundation Ireland’s strategy Agenda 2020.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Foundation Ireland Agenda2020|url=http://www.sfi.ie/resources/Agenga-2020.pdf|website=sfi.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> This also aligns to the national science innovation strategy, Innovation 2020.<ref>{{cite web|title=Innovation 2020|url=https://dbei.gov.ie/en/Publications/Innovation-2020.html|publisher=Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref>
==History== Over the years, Science Week Ireland has grown from a small pilot initiative to a large promotional and event engine to its current identity as a recognised vehicle for regional activity supported by a national promotional campaign.<ref name="oak1">{{cite web|last1=Ahlstrom|first1=Dick|title=Science Week: From small acorn to giant oak tree . . .|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sponsored/science-week-from-small-acorn-to-giant-oak-tree-1.2403471|website=The Irish Times|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> The first Science Week in Ireland was held in 1996.<ref name="oak1"/> It was organised by Forfás on behalf of the Office of Science and Technology at the Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation under the name 'Information Technology and Science Week'. The week aimed to raise general awareness of the benefits of science and information technology to people, young and old throughout society. In 1997 it was renamed as Science Week. Professional bodies, voluntary groups, colleges, businesses and the public sector combined to organise 50 events countrywide.<ref name="oak1"/> Events included conferences, lectures, interactive exhibitions, debates, and competitions for primary school students.
SFI took over Science Week from the Forfás Discover Science and Engineering programme in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=New legislation to focus scientific research on turning good ideas into good jobs|url=https://www.irishbuildingmagazine.ie/2012/12/12/new-legislation-to-focus-scientific-research-on-turning-good-ideas-into-good-jobs|publisher=Irish Building Magazine|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> Science Week continued to grow and develop over the following years into what it represents today, a week-long<ref name="sfi ie1">{{cite web|title=Science Week|url=http://www.sfi.ie/engagement/science-week/|website=sfi.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> celebration of STEM public engagement, enhancing the public’s interest in STEM and enabling them to see the relevance of STEM to their daily lives.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Foundation Ireland Discover Programme Call 2017|url=http://www.sfi.ie/funding/funding-calls/sfi-discover-programme/1.-SFI-Discover-Programme-Call-2017-FINAL.pdf|website=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2007 == Science Week 2007 took place between 11–18 November and the theme was "Surrounded by Science".<ref>[http://www.kildare.ie/community/notices/education/surrounded_by_science.asp Article on Science Week - Kildare.ie website]</ref> The programme of events set out to illustrate that behind the everyday objects in our lives is a great inventor, scientist or engineer. This included a series of lectures<ref>[http://www.pkellypr.com/blog/2007/1026/science-week-lecture-series/ Blog about Science Week]</ref> which featured [[Craig Johnston]], inventor of the [[Adidas Predator]]; [[Joe F. Edwards, Jr.]], former [[NASA]] [[astronaut]]; and Dr. Sheila Willis, Director of the [[Forensic Science]] [[Laboratory]].<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2006/1113/index.html Article on Science Week] ''Irish Times''</ref>
2007 was the eleventh year of Science Week and saw an estimated 95,000 people attend lectures, [[art exhibition|exhibitions]] and [[workshop]]s throughout the country.<ref>[http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2007/11/08/story47374.asp Article on Science Week - Irish Examiner Newspaper]</ref><ref>[http://www.ucd.ie/cscb/main_pages/news/news261107.html Article on Science Week - Centre for Synthesis and Chemical Biology]</ref><ref>[http://www.waterford-today.ie/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1458&Itemid=10107&ed=124 Article on Science Week - Galway Today Newspaper]</ref>
== Science Week 2008 == The 2008 Science Week took place between 11–16 November. The theme was 'Science – Shaping Our World' which celebrates the [[International Year of Planet Earth]].
The guest lecturers include Professor [[Aubrey Manning]], distinguished zoologist and broadcaster; Gerry Johnston, director of Special Effects Ireland; Dr. [[Cynthia Breazeal]], Associate Professor at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]; Stephen Attenborough of [[Virgin Galactic]]; and [[Patrick Collison]], Irish Young Scientist of the Year winner 2005. These can be viewed on YouTube.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/user/DSEvideo#grid/user/0DC6E2B53E5BC483 ]</ref>
== Science Week 2009 == Science Week 2009 took place between 8–15 November. The theme was 'Science – Inspiring Creativity and Innovation’, which links to the European Year of Creativity and Innovation.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090313202726/http://www.create2009.europa.eu/ European Year of Creativity and Innovation]</ref>
In the summer of 2009, DSE launched a Twitter account for the latest news on Science Week.
A lecture series included speakers from the [[Tyndall National Institute]], Cork and Sustainable Energy Ireland. These can be viewed on YouTube.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/user/DSEvideo#grid/user/497DA36AD42C7F19 ]</ref>
== Science Week 2010 == Science Week 2010 ran from 7-14 November. Its theme was ‘Our Place in Space’, which explored the latest happenings in astronomy, Ireland’s role in the space industry, and the vital role played by science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) in helping us to make sense of our universe.<ref>{{cite web|title=DPSM Newsletter: Science Week 2010|url=http://www.primaryscience.ie/resources_enewsletter_edition22_art6.php|website=Primaryscience.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2011 == Science Week 2011 ran from 13–20 November. The theme was 'The Chemistry of Life', demonstrating the importance of chemistry to our everyday lives – from the atoms that are the building blocks of nature to the chemistry that creates lasting bonds between people.<ref>{{cite web|title=DPSM Newsletter: Science Week 2011: The Chemistry of Life|url=http://www.primaryscience.ie/resources_enewsletter_edition25_art01.php|website=primaryscience.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2012 == Science Week 2012 ran from 11–18 November. The theme was ‘Everyday Experimenting’, highlighting how we are all involved in science every day, carrying out scientific processes and experimenting, even when not aware of it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week 2012: Everyday Experimenting|url=http://www.explorationdome.ie/science-week-2012-everyday-experimenting/|website=Exploration Dome|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2013 == Science Week 2013 ran from 10-17 November. The theme was ‘Exploring the XTRA-Ordinary’, which called on the public to go ‘behind the scenes’ of everyday life and explore the extraordinary processes taking place in front of our eyes.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Courtney|first1=Kevin|title=At your service: the complex science behind everyday dilemmas|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/science/at-your-service-the-complex-science-behind-everyday-dilemmas-1.1585955|website=The Irish Times|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2014 == An estimated 250,000 people took part in science festivals, demonstrations, seminars and tours across the country during the 19th annual national Science Week, which took place from 9-16 November 2014.<ref name="key">{{cite web|title=Key objective of Science Week is to inspire young people to take up careers in area|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/science/key-objective-of-science-week-is-to-inspire-young-people-to-take-up-careers-in-area-1.1971458|website=The Irish Times|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> The theme was ‘Power of Science’.<ref name="key"/> Over 800 events took place across Ireland, including science festivals in Sligo, Galway, Mayo, Dublin, Cork, Waterford and the Midlands, aiming to "entertain, educate and enthral young and old alike with the power of science".<ref>{{cite web|title=Firing the imagination and celebrating the power of science|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/education/firing-the-imagination-and-celebrating-the-power-of-science-30735349.html|website=Independent.ie|publisher=The Irish Independent|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> Jamie Heaslip acted as a Science Week ambassador.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jamie Heaslip to line out as the ambassador of National Science Week|url=http://entertainment.ie/trending/news/Jamie-Heaslip-to-line-out-as-the-ambassador-of-National-Science-Week/310775.htm|website=entertainment.ie|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2015 == 2015 marked the 20th anniversary of Science Week, which took place from 8-15 November.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kelly|first1=Caroline|title=Science Week 2.0: Design Your Future|url=https://www.mykidstime.com/things-to-do/science-week-2-0-design-your-future/|website=mkidstime.com|publisher=My Kids Time|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> The theme was ‘Science Week 2.0 Design Your Future’. It celebrated how science empowers ‘you’ to ‘Design Your Future’.<ref>{{cite web|title=Join the fun at Science Week 2015|url=http://www.limerickpost.ie/2015/11/10/science-week/|publisher=Limerick Post|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> Numerous events were held in every county, and regional festivals took place in Mayo, Sligo, Galway, Waterford, Cork, Limerick and the midlands.<ref>{{cite web|title=20th science week supports Ireland’s appetite for science, technology, engineering & maths|url=http://www.researchandinnovation.ie/20th-science-week-supports-irelands-appetite-for-science-technology-engineering-maths/|publisher=Research and Innovation|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2016 == Science Week 2016 took place from 13-20 November.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week: Embracing the world around us|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sponsored/science-week-embracing-the-world-around-us-1.2807368|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> The theme was ‘Science Rising’ which looks at how science is key to our success – it is part of our past, an important part of our present and there is endless potential still to be realised.<ref>{{cite web|title=Minister Mary Mitchell O’Connor announces recipients of Science Foundation Ireland Discover Science and Maths Award|url=https://dbei.gov.ie/en/News-And-Events/Department-News/2016/June/27062016a.html|website=Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation|publisher=Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> Science Week 2016 reached more people, all over Ireland, across a wider demographic than had been achieved before.<ref>{{cite web|title=The science of everyday things|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sponsored/the-science-of-everyday-things-1.2859338|website=The Irish Times Online|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> Science Week 2016 saw 10 Regional Festivals across the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week 2016|url=https://www.itsligo.ie/science-week/|publisher=IT Sligo}}</ref>
== Science Week 2017 == Science Week 2017 ran nationwide from 12-19 November 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week 2017: 12-19 November|url=https://www.rte.ie/lifestyle/science-week/2017/1102/917085-science-week-2017/|website=rte.ie|publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> The theme was ‘Believe in Science’. More than 1180 events took place across Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Foundation Ireland Events|url=http://www.sfi.ie/events/|website=sfi.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref> 12 regional science festivals took place in Cavan/Monaghan, Cork, Carlow, Festival of Farming and Food (Teagasc), Galway, Kerry, Limerick, Mayo, the Midlands, Sligo, Southeast and Tipperary.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week Festivals|url=http://www.sfi.ie/events/festivals/|website=sfi.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
A number of Science Foundation Ireland-funded Science Week events took place throughout the week, including events by the Ark Theatre,<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week at The Ark|url=http://ark.ie/events/season/science-week-at-the-ark|website=The Ark|publisher=The Ark|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> The British Council of Ireland,<ref>{{cite web|title=Art in Mind – Explore the Interplay between the Arts and Science|url=https://www.nationalgallery.ie/art-mind-explore-interplay-between-arts-and-science|website=nationalgallery.ie|publisher=The National Gallery of Ireland|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> Dublinia,<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week 2017 at Dublinia|url=http://www.dublinia.ie/events_news/from-the-shovel-to-the-microscope-changing-the-perception-of-archaeology/|website=Dublinia.ie|publisher=Dublinia|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> Dunsink Observatory,<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week at Dunsink Observatory|url=https://www.dias.ie/2017/11/06/science-week-at-dunsink-observatory/|website=dias.ie|publisher=Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> Foodoppi,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larkin|first1=Aisling|title=Science Week 2017 Eat Your Science|url=http://foodoppi.com/science-week-2017/|website=Foodoppi.com|publisher=Foodoppi|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> Learnit Educational Solutions,<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week|url=https://www.learnit.ie/science-week|website=learnit.ie|publisher=Learnit|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> the Science Gallery,<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week Screening: Bodytech|url=https://dublin.sciencegallery.com/events/2017/11/scienceweekscreeningbodytech|website=dublin.sciencegallery.com|publisher=Science Gallery|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Makeshop on the Road for Science Week|url=https://dublin.sciencegallery.com/events/2016/11/makeshoproadscienceweek|website=dublin.sciencegallery.com|publisher=Science Gallery|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> ADAPT,<ref>{{cite web|title=Irish Mental Health Legacies of the Great Famine|url=https://www.adaptcentre.ie/about/events/irish-mental-health-legacies-of-the-great-famine|website=Adapt Centre|publisher=ADAPT Centre for Digital Content Technology|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> The Rediscovery Centre<ref>{{cite web|title=Lets Talk Science Festival|url=http://www.rediscoverycentre.ie/lets-talk-science-festival/|website=rediscoverycentre.ie|publisher=Rediscovery Centre|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> and Wexford Co. Council.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week 2017|url=https://www.wexfordcoco.ie/libraries/more-library-services/children/science-week-2017|website=wexfordcoco.ie|publisher=Wexford County Council|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> The Scintillating Science event with Dara O'Briain launched the beginning of Science Week in the National Concert Hall,<ref>{{cite web|title=Scintillating Science with Dara Ó Briain|url=https://dublin.ie/whats-on/listings/scintillating-science-with-dara-o-briain/|website=Dublin.ie|publisher=Dublin.ie|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Blake Knox|first1=Kirsty|title=Robots to provide home help for elderly|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/technology/news/robots-to-provide-home-help-for-elderly-36317585.html|website=independent.ie|publisher=The Irish Independent|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> and the Dublin Science Week Family Open Day at the Convention Centre Dublin was held at the end of the week.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dublin Science Week Family Open Day|url=https://www.eventbrite.ie/e/dublin-science-week-family-open-day-tickets-39038279545#|website=eventbrite.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland via Event Brite|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
During Science Week 2017, SFI launched the #StopAndAsk social media campaign which calls on people to ask questions about the world around them.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kennedy|first1=John|title=Science Week: Why we need to talk more about science|url=https://www.siliconrepublic.com/innovation/science-week-ireland-national-knowledge-conversation|website=siliconrepublic.com|publisher=Silicon Republic|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week 2017: Finding the science in everyday things|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sponsored/science-foundation-ireland/science-week-2017-finding-the-science-in-everyday-things-1.3284570|website=irishtimes.com|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> Science Foundation Ireland, its partners and the science community answered a selection of these questions throughout the week.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/hashtag/StopAndAsk?src=hash&lang=en|website=Twitter|publisher=Science Week Twitter Account (Science Foundation Ireland)|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> A show reel of some highlights of Science Week 2017 can be viewed on YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week 2017 Highlights|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gYavlen-k6c|website=YouTube|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland via YouTube|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
== Science Week 2018 == Science Week 2018 will run from 11-18 November 2018.<ref name="sfi ie1"/>
== How to get involved == The SFI website outlines tips on how to get involved with Science Week in Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|title=Science Week: How to get Involved|url=http://www.sfi.ie/engagement/science-week/get-involved/|website=sfi.ie|publisher=Science Foundation Ireland|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.forfas.ie Forfás website] *[http://www.scienceweek.ie Science Week Ireland website] *[http://www.djei.ie/ Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation website] *[http://www.discover-science.ie/programmes-and-audiences/science-week Information about Science Week on Discover-Science.ie] *{{twitter|scienceweek}} *{{twitter|irelandscience|Science.ie}} - Irish science news, events and links on Twitter

page.title: Sexualization and sexual exploitation in K-pop

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: ever present → ever-present, June of 1996 → June 1996, 1980’s → 1980s (14), Korea’s → Korea's (14)
revision.text:
[[File:TaeTiSeo at Suncheon Bay Garden Expo International K-POP Concert 2013 03.jpg|alt=A 2013 live performance of Girls' Generation-TTS exemplifying Lolita-esque cuteness|thumb|A 2013 live performance of [[Girls' Generation-TTS]] exemplifying Lolita-esque cuteness]] [[K-pop]] started to become [[Sexualization|sexualized]] around the turn of the 21<sup>st</sup> century with its maturation<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/893686334|title=K-pop : popular music, cultural amnesia, and economic innovation in South Korea|last=John|first=Lie|publisher=|year=|isbn=9780520958944|location=Oakland, California|pages=|oclc=893686334}}</ref> due to globalization<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Gooyong|date=|title=Korean Wave{{!}} Between Hybridity and Hegemony in K-Pop’s Global Popularity: A Case of "Girls’ Generation’s" American Debut|url=https://ijoc.org/index.php/ijoc/article/view/6306|journal=International Journal of Communication|volume=11|pages=2367–2386|via=}}</ref> and the advent of music videos on social media/[[YouTube]].<ref name=":3">{{cite thesis|last=Song|first=Bohye|title=Seeing is Believing: Content Analysis of Sexual Content in Korean Music Videos|date=2016|publisher=Southern Utah University|url=https://www.suu.edu/hss/comm/masters/capstone/thesis/b-song.pdf|type=Masters}}</ref> Korean popular music was originally more conservative in the 1980s, took on the Japanese idol system during the 1990s,<ref name=":1" /> brought the western male gaze<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Puzar|first=Aljosa|date=|title=Asian Dolls and the Westernized Gaze: Notes on the Female Dollification in South Korea|url=|journal=Asian Women|volume=27(2)|pages=81-111|via=}}</ref> and Lolita culture in the 2000s,<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Yeran|date=December 2011|title=Idol republic: the global emergence of girl industries and the commercialization of girl bodies|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09589236.2011.617604|journal=Journal of Gender Studies|volume=20|issue=4|pages=333–345|doi=10.1080/09589236.2011.617604|issn=0958-9236|via=}}</ref> and morphed into a global phenomenon by the 2010s.<ref name=":1" /> Currently, [[Korean idol|K-pop idols]] are manufactured to optimize profit, making keen use of fan desires.<ref name=":1" /> In general, female and male idols follow normative femininity and masculinity, respectively, as defined by the South Korean patriarchal system, in conjunction with a globally desired façade.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Epstein|first=Stephen|last2=Joo|first2=Rachael M.|date=|title=Multiple Exposures: Korean Bodies and the Transnational Imagination|url=https://apjjf.org/2012/10/33/Stephen-Epstein/3807/article.html|journal=The Asia-Pacific Journal|volume=10(33)|pages=|via=}}</ref> Femininity is often defined by a suppressed [[Doll fetish|doll state]] conforming to [[Lolita (term)|Lolita]] ideals, presenting skinny bodies, long legs and perfect faces.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/488932704|title=The Lolita effect : the media sexualization of young girls and what we can do about it|last=Gigi|first=Durham, Meenakshi|date=2009|publisher=Overlook Press|isbn=9781590202159|oclc=488932704}}</ref> Masculinity follows a soft masculinity, or cosmopolitan masculinity, in that males are required to be strong and virile, but have soft features such as sweet personality traits or a cute face.<ref name=":8">{{cite thesis|last=Leung|first=Sarah|title=Catching the K-Pop Wave: Globality in the Production, Distribution, and Consumption of South Korean Popular Music|date=2012|publisher=Vassar College|url=https://digitalwindow.vassar.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1151&context=senior_capstone|type=Batchlors}}</ref> The manifestation of sexualization can be seen in all parts of the idol republic, but is normally seen in modern music videos, which have become more sexualized over the last decade.<ref name=":3" /> Additionally, it should be noted that female idols are often objectified more than male idols, something that is complementary to the patriarchal Korean culture.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Lin|first=Xi|last2=Rudolf|first2=Robert|date=|title=Does K-pop Reinforce Gender Inequalities? Empirical Evidence from a New Data Set|url=|journal=Asian Women|volume=33(4)|pages=27-54|via=}}</ref>
== Historical Context == The advent of modern K-pop arguably started in 1992, gained significant foothold by 1996 during the industrialization of K-pop, matured through the mid 2000s,<ref name=":1" /> and flourished in the 2010s.<ref name=":3" /> Albeit beauty is an ever-present ideal for Korean popular culture, these time periods represent shifts in beauty norms and K-pop ideals.<ref name=":1" /> The early 1990s brought a young, individualistic cuteness to the scene with stocky builds and chubby faces, following from the Korean beauty norms of the 1980s.<ref name=":1" /> Following the 1980s Japanese idol system, idol groups were generated in the late 1990s, often mimicking western boy bands with innocence and sunny dispositions, a product directed domestically. During this time a review committee censored all Korean music and music videos for sexual and other explicit content.<ref name=":3" /> The committee was disbanded in June 1996.<ref name=":3" /> After an economic crisis in 1997 and success of this domestic product outside South Korea, the innocence morphed into a more romantic and hipper image in the early 2000s, which presented the first major signs of sexualization.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" /> This transformation was aided by the increased use of music videos.<ref name=":3" /> By 2004 a new generation of K-pop was born, sex became prevalent in K-pop and idol-worshiping adolescents came into being.<ref name=":3" /> Within a decade, maturation of K-pop, driven by hyper-popularized music videos, propelled idols into a visual medium, thus transforming K-pop into the modern beauty standard of low body fat, well-toned muscles, and perfected body features.<ref name=":1" />
=== Globalization === The late 2000s brought K-pop into its modern era and introduced it to the international stage with the [[Korean Wave|Korean wave]] in Asia; the early 2010s bolstered K-pop to an international powerhouse with the global Korean wave. K-pop has always been influenced by western musical styles; however, many link its international success to the globalization caused by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout period (during the 1997 South Korean economic crash) in South Korea's neoliberalization.<ref name=":2" /> Post-IMF South Korea has incorporated more Westernized (specifically, Americanized) culture into their products (i.e. exports) in order to prosper in international sales, thus pressing the popular music industry to become more westernized.<ref name=":2" /> Integration of westernization brought the western male gaze<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /> and the hypersexualization of products, especially in the popular music scene.<ref name=":2" /> Not only was the music itself altered to enhance exportability, but given the modern age of the music video, the performer was also altered.<ref name=":2" /> Combining this with Korea's male dominated society, one that currently ranks the near the bottom of the Global Gender Gap list for modernized societies (presenting the largest gender wage and working condition gaps), produces an overtly sexualized popular music market.<ref name=":9" /> Additionally, proliferation of K-pop allows for South Korea to enter into and even dominate the global “cultural war,” a concept tied to a battle for attention between the globalized cultures in the modern era. Thus, the government of South Korea encourages the use of K-pop to promote global recognition; however, because of the turbulence of popular culture, largely due to sexualization and exploitation, the government maintains no official backing of K-pop but restrains limiting what are allowable K-pop activities.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Saeji|first=CedarBough T.|date=December 2013|title=Juvenile Protection and Sexual Objectification: Analysis of the Performance Frame in Korean Music Television Broadcasts|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.18399/acta.2013.16.2.003|journal=Acta Koreana|volume=16|issue=2|pages=329–365|doi=10.18399/acta.2013.16.2.003|issn=1520-7412|via=}}</ref> Ergo, without official sponsorship of K-pop, the government unofficially helps it by reducing governmental constraints on it, especially for exported products.<ref name=":5" /> This allows the idols to become an unofficial representation of the South Korean culture, promoting cultural pride and building the nation into an “idol republic,” meaning that their image (i.e. bodies) belong to the state and represent the state's people.<ref name=":5" />
== Critical Issues == Sexualization in K-pop is mainly driven by economic reasoning and forces females into a globalized normative femininity and males into a globalized normative masculinity.
=== Economic Reasoning === Entering the world market to help globalize marketable Korean culture was only a byproduct of the economic conditions behind K-pop's evolution. Early K-pop was not well received critically, but its catchiness and localization enamored the masses.<ref name=":1" /> The success was noticed by a few business-oriented musicians that soon capitalized on the situation.<ref name=":1" /> Industrialization of K-pop occurred around the mid 1990s and its popularity grew.<ref name=":1" /> Maintaining localization while hybridizing (not assimilating) with Japan's idol methodology and American popular music stylings helped bolster success internally and as an export, albeit initially limited.<ref name=":1" /> The promising external success in conjunction with the diverse extant musical acts drove the music industry to facilitate portfolio diversification of their performing groups to maximize success and thus, profits. This meant optimized pandering to the most consumers. Such optimization lead to increasing numbers of performers per group, each individualized to suit different consumers’ tastes, perfecting the performances, and increasing attractiveness of the group to the different consuming cultures.<ref name=":1" /> Therefore, in the group itself there could be a proverbial “good,” “bad,” cute, or sexy member, while the whole group increased in attractiveness.<ref name=":1" /> Also, combining the desires of American culture for blatant sexiness,<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Unger|first=Michael A.|date=March 2015|title=The Aporia of Presentation: Deconstructing the Genre of K-pop Girl Group Music Videos in South Korea|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/jpms.12109|journal=Journal of Popular Music Studies|volume=27|issue=1|pages=25–47|doi=10.1111/jpms.12109|issn=1524-2226|via=}}</ref> Korean culture for [[aegyo]] (a compound of cute and lovable),<ref name=":4" /> and Japanese proclivity for [[kawaii]] and patriarchal Lolita ideas made a complex interplay of diverse satisfaction of fantastical desires.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> Following this logic, the music companies substantially invested monetarily and temporally in each performer in an effort to tailor them.<ref name=":1" /> A base level of attractiveness and skill is required to be considered as a performer.<ref name=":1" /> Years of subsequent training and discipline mold performers into what the public wants to see.<ref name=":1" /> They are disallowed from dating to maintain innocence,<ref name=":1" /> have a directed public life and persona (often sexualized or cute), shamed for gaining (or in some cases not losing) weight or not keeping their appearance up, may be required to go through plastic surgery for beautification,<ref name=":11" /> and are required to interact with fans in a desirable manner.<ref name=":1" /> All-in-all, K-pop is an industry driven by profit; subsequently, it treats its performers like well-molded commodities in order to adhere to consumer desires, often sexual in nature as in the westernized (male) gaze, and Lolita ideals.
=== Femininity === As the flagship cultural commodities of South Korea, female K-pop singers are expected to be sexy, strong, and independent, in conjunction with being a product for the patriarchal South Korean capitalist society, which wants them to be submissive, innocent, cute, and loveable.<ref name=":9" /> To maximize profit and success, the female stars must have the guise of ambiguity.<ref name=":5" /> Ultimately, the ambiguity results as a clash between virgin and whore, which nearly all groups have; however, some of them may be more biased to one side than the other.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Hazzan|first=Dave|date=|title=K-pop Chords of Sexism|url=http://www.davehazzan.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Herizons-v30n2-Fall16.pdf|journal=herizons|volume=30(2)|pages=44-45|via=}}</ref> South Korean ideals nominally press an aegyo image, or one that is “attractive and desirable beyond limits of intimate relations,” providing vulnerability to the idols but keeping them whimsical.<ref name=":4" /> To conform to the westernized male gaze, females take the part of an exotic sexual object,<ref name=":9" /> often under the dollified Asian motif, leading to thoughts of “convenient Asians.”<ref name=":4" /> Dollification is a construct of placing sexual desire upon a submissive and uncorrupted object of beauty, something common to Asia due to traditional gender roles and patriarchal structure, and applies exceptionally well to the surgically beautified K-pop females.<ref name=":4" /> Additionally, dolls are often associated with prostitution or sexual favors, something that idol singers can face when exploited by their employers.<ref name=":4" /> Dollification also plays into the Japanese desire for submissive kawaii: dolls are inherently cute and can be controlled at will, something that quenches the yearning for totally submissive females.<ref name=":4" /> Similarly, the concept of middle-aged Korean males seeing themselves as Samchon-fans (uncle-fans), or enduring uncles to the idols, has been argued as a facade to deny sexual desire when there is actually an underlying sexual gratification from the female bodies.<ref name=":5" /> This makes the female idol fill a Lolita role, one which fulfills a market need by supplying a male pedophilic fantasy of a young female with unconscious sexuality.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" /> Consequently, girl (female) bodies have become a commodity and given implicit subjugation in the patriarchal structure, the consumption of such is acceptable.<ref name=":5" /> The females may present “girl power” given their high popularity status, but their pawn-like nature under the might of their parent companies keeps this a novelty, not a reality, via pacification.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> The justified objectification of girl bodies in such an idol republic, where it is promoted economically and governmentally, makes it a Lolita republic, as argued by Yeran Kim.<ref name=":5" /> More simply, their bodies’ beauty can belong to a national collective.<ref name=":6" /> This beauty and femininity in image is prominently described as that of long legs with “honey thighs” and a perfect face and body, while showing ample skin; breasts are often sexualized but have only recently been presented as cleavage in K-pop due to the lack of cleavage shown in the general Korean culture.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":6" />
=== Masculinity === Paralleling female idols, male idols are also commodities to be sexualized in an effort to maximize profit and success. Given the rigorous patriarchal gender rolls existing in Korea, the males are normally subjected to the requirement of Korean masculinity, but to optimize for diverse target audiences, they often present vulnerabilities, forming a non-Korean masculinity.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/840865016|title=Korean masculinities and transcultural consumption Yonsama, Rain, Oldboy, K-Pop idols|last=Sun.|first=Jung,|date=2011|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|oclc=840865016}}</ref> Korean (hegemonic) masculinity can consist of patriarchal authority, traditional Confucian masculinity, and violence.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/46240370|title=Under construction : the gendering of modernity, class, and consumption in the Republic of Korea|last=Laurel.|first=Kendall,|date=2002|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=0824824075|oclc=46240370}}</ref> Contradictorily, non-Korean masculinity contains a range of metrosexuality from charming to chic.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13" /> This dichotomy forces bands to be muscular, potent, and appearing sexually virile, while injecting cuteness and innocence into their presentation, creating a transnational “soft masculinity” and “global metrosexual masculinity.”<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13" /> Both a soft masculinity called “flower boys,” and a harder masculinity, called “beast idols,” appear in K-pop groups, but even the hardest K-pop masculinity maintains a globalized cuteness.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/column/k-pop-generation/article/2013/10/22/Kpop_Men_Gender_Roles_Soy/|title=Men in K-Pop: From “Flower Boys” to “Beast-dols”|last=Soyoung|first=Kim|date=October 22, 2013|website=The Harvard Crimson|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170325192647/https://www.thecrimson.com/column/k-pop-generation/article/2013/10/22/Kpop_Men_Gender_Roles_Soy/|archive-date=March 25, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The key features of K-pop masculinity are muscular (often nude) torsos and cute actions/personalities.<ref name=":6" /> Well-defined muscles, albeit a falsity, can be considered a sign of both individual phallic power in response to feministic movements and nationalistic female desires.<ref name=":6" /> This is exemplified by a “body price” (momgap) notion that equates the sexiness of a male body to its (and his) worth,<ref name=":6" /> with “chocolate abs” being the most desirable trait.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":6" /> Emasculated actions/personalities are often subtly employed to diversify the K-pop masculine act,<ref name=":6" /> as previously stated, but have occasionally been stressed by some to help break gender norms.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=https://www.soompi.com/article/1079057wpp/8-k-pop-idols-challenging-gender-norms-korea|title=8 K-Pop Idols Who Are Challenging Gender Norms In Korea|last=heytoto|first=|date=November 28, 2017|website=soompi|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> However, removing masculinity as a whole is ineffective, as noted by a Korean studies professor Oh Ingyu of Korea University, Seoul, “[a] male star without well-defined muscles, six-pack abs and a handsome smile won’t go far.”<ref name=":12" /> As stated by Sarah Leung “[the K-pop industry’s] ultimate goal? To sell an image to the screaming girls in the crowd.”<ref name=":8" />
== Manifestation == Sexualization of the popular Korean music market takes place in many forms: pushing sexy and attractive performers, conforming the performers to fan fantasies, and presenting sexualized songs or music videos.<ref name=":5" />
=== Dollification === Dollification can be observed in a Japanese quote on the introduction to a performance by [[Girls' Generation|Girls’ Generation]] “I was shocked by their amazingly beautiful legs. The dance was as if dolls were dancing and it was wondrous.”<ref name=":6" /> Likewise, employers utilized doll images for advertisement. The idol [[G.NA]]’s body measurements were a hot topic with fans, so her employer promoted her by juxtaposing her with mannequins during photoshoots while calling her body “the mannequin body” because of her small face, large breasts, and small waist.<ref name=":4" /> This representation of a dollified human parallels Girl's Generation's “Gee” music video, in which the members are acting as mannequins in a shop's window that soon come alive or [[Girl's Day|Girl's Day]]’s music video for “Tilt my Head,” in which the members act like doll factory automata producing self-similar dolls that magically come alive (both also following the “coming alive” narrative).<ref name=":4" /> Countering the description of a perfect doll image is the group Piggy Dolls, consisting of three heavier set females, engendering diversity in body image.<ref name=":4" />
=== Female idol bodies === In general, K-pop idol bodies are heavily regulated by their employers; in fact, female bodies are not considered their own, as presented by a snarky statement by a member of [[Super Junior]], "[Girls’ Generation] can't get hurt without permission. Their bodies aren't their own. They're treasures of the nation."<ref name=":6" /> Consequently, female idols need to conform to image norms. A normative male gaze desires long legs, something Girls’ Generation has in multitudes, as exemplified by a Japanese nickname “The Beautiful Legs Group,” and has even spawned a Japanese pornographic film based on their legs.<ref name=":6" /> Similarly, bodily perfection is a requirement of the profit-driven entertainment kingpins. An out of shape body can be put through training to lose weight, such as done by the Piggy Dolls for a comeback,<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://seoulbeats.com/2013/09/piggy-girls-making-comeback-im-smiling/|title=Piggy Dolls Are Making a Comeback: Why I’m Not Smiling|last=Gabrielle|first=|date=September 9, 2013|website=seoulbeats|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180406102526/http://seoulbeats.com:80/2013/09/piggy-girls-making-comeback-im-smiling|archive-date=April 6, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> who lost a total of 56 kg.<ref name=":18">{{Cite web|url=https://www.generasia.com/wiki/Piggy_Dolls|title=Piggy Dolls|last=|first=|date=|website=generasia|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180329203009/http://www.generasia.com:80/wiki/Piggy_Dolls|archive-date=March 29, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Often encountered is a trainee with a good body but bad face, and fixing this imperfection is often accomplished by their employer enforcing mandatory plastic surgery (with the exception of [[YG Entertainment|YG entertainment]], who prohibits plastic surgery); not getting a mandatory surgery can mean career failure.<ref name=":19">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pri.org/stories/2016-04-25/k-pop-s-gross-double-standard-women|title=K-pop’s Gross Double Standard for Women|last=Volodzko|first=David|date=April 25, 2016|website=Public Radio International|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908120956/https://www.pri.org/stories/2016-04-25/k-pop-s-gross-double-standard-women|archive-date=September 8, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Although any surgery is dangerous and can have complications,<ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|last=Elfving-Hwang|first=Joanna|date=June 16, 2013|title=Cosmetic Surgery and Embodying the Moral Self in South Korean Popular Makeover Culture|url=https://apjjf.org/2013/11/24/Joanna-Elfving-Hwang/3956/article.html|journal=The Asia-Pacific Journal|volume=11(24)|pages=|via=}}</ref> it is very common to have small aesthetic plastic surgeries and moderately common to have semi-reconstructive surgeries, to the point that a large number of K-pop stars have undergone some form of plastic surgery. Common modifications are a double-eyelid addition, rhinoplasty, chin shaving,<ref name=":21">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/934514703|title=Behind South Korean cosmetic surgery : its historical causes and its intertwined relationship with Korean pop culture|last=Yuqing.|first=Wang,|date=2015|isbn=9781321989939|oclc=934514703}}</ref> and muscular reshaping (legs mainly).<ref name=":6" /> There are some idols who have openly admitted to aesthetic surgeries, such as Miryo of [[Brown Eyed Girls]], who had a double eyelid surgery, Goo Hara of [[Kara (South Korean band)|KARA]] with an eyelid alteration, and Jessi who had breast implants, rhinoplasty, and surgery on her eyelids.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/03/28/8-idols-whove-discussed-their-plastic-surgery|title=8 Idols Who've Discussed Their Plastic Surgery|last=|first=|date=March 28, 2018|website=SBS|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107072347/https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/03/28/8-idols-whove-discussed-their-plastic-surgery|archive-date=November 7, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Some even act as spokespeople for plastic surgery offices, such as G.Na with a statement of “[c]ome and become more beautiful” for Dr. Jong Phil.<ref name=":23">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/05/the-k-pop-plastic-surgery-obsession/276215/|title=The K-Pop Plastic Surgery Obsession|last=Stone|first=Zara|date=May 24, 2013|website=The Atlantic|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181027132247/https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/05/the-k-pop-plastic-surgery-obsession/276215/|archive-date=October 27, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> However, most artists keep enhancements private, so there is great conjecture of K-pop idols that may have had plastic surgery, including even the biggest names, such as members of Girls’ Generation<ref name=":24">{{Cite web|url=https://plastytalk.com/truth-behind-kpop-snsd-plastic-surgery/|title=The Truth Behind K-pop SNSD Plastic Surgery|last=K.|first=Sandy|date=April 6, 2016|website=PlastyTalk.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171213120816/https://plastytalk.com/truth-behind-kpop-snsd-plastic-surgery/|archive-date=December 3, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and [[Hyuna|Huyna]],<ref name=":25">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ranker.com/list/kpop-female-idols-before-and-after-plastic-surgery/onlysuy|title=K-pop Female Idols Before and After Plastic Surgery|last=|first=|date=|website=Ranker|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170830111928/http://www.ranker.com:80/list/kpop-female-idols-before-and-after-plastic-surgery/onlysuy|archive-date=August 30, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> among others. With so much conjecture, some singers, such as Lee Hyori and Jang Yoon-Ju, amongst other famous Koreans, have even gone so far as to medically prove they have had no breast augmentation done to defend themselves.<ref name=":26">{{Cite web|url=https://www.koreaboo.com/lists/haters-accused-female-idols-breast-implants-proved-them-wrong/|title=Haters Accused These Female Idols Of Breast Implants…So They Proved Them Wrong|last=|first=|date=March 16, 2018|website=Koreaboo|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107073117/https://www.koreaboo.com/lists/haters-accused-female-idols-breast-implants-proved-them-wrong/|archive-date=November 7, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> On the other hand, the group Six Bomb has embraced plastic surgery and has even made a song and music video called “Getting Pretty After” extolling it.<ref name=":27">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/39302637/K-pop-band-six-bomb-celebrate-plastic-surgery-with-before-and-after-videos|title=K-Pop band Six Bomb 'celebrate' plastic surgery with before and after videos|last=|first=|date=March 17, 2017|website=BBC|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180428090721/http://www.bbc.co.uk:80/newsbeat/article/39302637/k-pop-band-six-bomb-celebrate-plastic-surgery-with-before-and-after-videos|archive-date=April 28, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In fact, their manager, Kim Il-woong, has openly admitted to all the members getting surgical augmentations to their faces and breasts.<ref name=":27" /> This type of candor and idolization system of K-pop has actually affected much of the youth and general Korean culture to desire plastic surgery in an effort to emulate their favorite stars.<ref name=":23" /> This fact has helped drive South Korea to have the most cosmetic surgeries per capita out of anywhere in the world.<ref name=":6" /> However, challenging these norms are idols such as [[Amber Liu (singer)|Amber]] from [[F(x) (band)|f(x)]], who wears male shorts, cuts her hair short, and even jokes about her “missing breasts.”<ref name=":16" />
=== Male idol bodies === Males are likewise subjected to rigorous body standards, with a requirement to keep up their “body price”<ref name=":6" /> while balancing their soft masculinity.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13" /> The singer Rain is the embodiment of effeminate hyper-masculinity.<ref name=":28">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/900162636|title=The Korean wave : Korean media go global|last=compilation|first=Kim, Youna, editor of|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415712781|oclc=900162636}}</ref> His well-defined abs and upper muscular body, often seen naked and oiled (or wet), is contrasted to his cute and young face.<ref name=":28" /> He is described as having “an angelic face and a killer body” or “a man’s body with a boy’s face.”<ref name=":28" /><ref name=":29">{{Cite journal|last=Shin|first=Hyunjoon|date=December 2009|title=Have you ever seen theRain? And who’ll stop theRain?: the globalizing project of Korean pop (K-pop)|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14649370903166150|journal=Inter-Asia Cultural Studies|volume=10|issue=4|pages=507–523|doi=10.1080/14649370903166150|issn=1464-9373|via=}}</ref> Rain is exemplary of the image required: a shirtless, muscular male, with some grounding cute elements. To keep this image, rigorous training is required, normally employing trainers and intense daily workout routines.<ref name=":6" /> As with their female counterparts, there is sometimes a need for plastic surgery. Similarly, conjecture exists for who has undergone surgery, but again, some idols have explicitly stated their surgical augmentations. For example, Kwanghee of [[ZE:A]] had eyelid, nose, and forehead alterations, Kim Heechul from Super Junior had eyelid alterations and fixed remnants of a past broken nose with surgery, and his co-star Kyuhyun (of Super Junior) had a double eyelid surgery following his parents example.<ref name=":22" /> It is important to note some of the gender norm challengers. Kim Heechul of Super Junior hosts a show “Lipstick Prince” to cover makeup for both genders, Ren from [[NU'EST|NU’EST]] modeled dresses, skirts, and other similar clothing, Lee Hong Ki of [[F.T. Island|FTISLAND]] both wears and promotes his nail art, Jo Kwon is a queer culture advocate and crossdresser, and Hansol enjoys makeup and has admitted to being non-heterosexual.<ref name=":16" />
=== Sexualization in YouTube music videos === {{See also|List of banned K-pop videos}} Given the popularization of K-pop through visual social media such as YouTube,<ref name=":1" /> many fans would most recognize sexualization in music videos or recorded performances. The advent of music videos to help brand recognition brought a survival-of-the-fittest attitude to the images of the artists; that is, the sexier artists survived.<ref name=":3" /> Therefore, sex was commercialized to capitalize on human reproductive nature, allowing sexualization to flourish.<ref name=":3" /> Given the liberalization of sex, sexual content has increased in K-pop music videos; therefore, a video content analysis was performed by Bohye Song by taking MelOn Hot 100 chart listings of the most popular Korean music videos of 2004, 2005, 2014, and 2015 to analyze their sexual content and increases over time.<ref name=":3" /> Content observed were sexual innuendos, sexual acts, and provocative clothing while the results were broken down into four parts of changes in physical affection, provocative dress, suggestiveness, and gender variance.<ref name=":3" /> It was found that displayed physical affections did not change on average, but implicit sex increased, sexual suggestiveness increased, provocative clothing increased, and female lead singers showed a significant increase in provocative display.<ref name=":3" /> This means that there is a significant increase in the display, mainly through clothing, of sexualized females and some males, but there is not much of an increase in sexual acts (two people in contact) depicted.<ref name=":3" /> This can be exemplified with modern music videos. Examples of K-pop music videos with revealing clothing on a female singer include “Marionette” by Stellar, “Roll Deep” by Hyuna, “Ring My Bell” by Girl's Day, “Wild” by [[Nine Muses (band)|Nine Muses]], “Wiggle Wiggle” by [[Hello Venus]], “Like a Cat” by [[AOA (band)|AOA]], “Butt” by I-Ren, and “Dr. Feel Good” by [[Rania (band)|BP RaNia]], among many others.<ref name=":30">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/K-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-female-edition|title=K-Pop idols' most revealing outfits [Female Edition]|last=|first=|date=May 22, 2017|website=allkpop|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180114013918/https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/k-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-female-edition|archive-date=January 14, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The female singers sported short skirts, short shorts, cleavage, tight clothing, et cetera.<ref name=":30" /> Correspondingly, male singers have worn see-through shirts and pants, extremely short shorts, and even corsets or skimpy dresses (in drag).<ref name=":31">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/K-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-male-edition|title=K-Pop idols' most revealing outfits [Male Edition]|last=|first=|date=May 24, 2017|website=allkpop|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115014357/https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/k-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-male-edition|archive-date=January 15, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Complementary to these are banned-from-broadcast videos, which include, but are not limited to, “MOMMAE” by [[Jay Park]], due to overtly sexualized females; “Abracadabra” by Brown Eyed Girls, for being sexually suggestive; “Mirotic” by [[TVXQ]], for body exposure and explicit language; “One More” by [[Fiestar|FIESTAR]], due to sexual imagery; both “Vibrato” and “Marionette” by [[Stellar (South Korean band)|Stellar]], for sexually suggestive dancing and clothing; “Touch Me” by Ivy, for sexual imagery and suggestive lyrics; “Joker” by [[Dal Shabet]], for sexual choreography; “Shower Later” by Gary, due to sexual innuendos and mature themes; and “Bae Bae” by [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|BIGBANG]], for sexual innuendos.<ref name=":32">{{Cite web|url=https://www.koreaboo.com/stories/10-K-pop-mvs-that-were-deemed-too-sexy-for-tv/|title=10 K-Pop MVs that have been banned for being “Too Sexual”|last=|first=|date=January 6, 2017|website=Koreaboo|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107074515/https://www.koreaboo.com/stories/10-K-pop-mvs-that-were-deemed-too-sexy-for-tv/|archive-date=November 7, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Lastly, the transition from innocent to sexualized can be shown by Girls’ Generation music videos.<ref name=":11" /> Their video for “[[Gee (Girls' Generation song)|Gee]]” in 2009 maintained schoolgirl innocence, then their video for “[[Oh! (Girls' Generation song)|Oh!]]” in 2010 kept their innocence but added on a prelude to their dark side at the end when it pitted the innocent schoolgirl cheerleaders against sexier, shadowy versions of themselves.<ref name=":11" /> Finally, their 2011 video for “[[The Boys (Girls' Generation song)|The Boys]]” replaced innocence with mature sexiness.<ref name=":11" />
== Controversies == Sexualization has a multitude of implications, causing controversies. One key controversy involves the disproportionate sexualization and objectification of females in comparison to males, perpetuating the patriarchal ideal of South Korea.
=== Gender inequalities === Both male and female K-pop idols are taken advantage of and objectified; however, females appear to have a disproportionate amount of sexism pitted against them.<ref name=":9" /> Females are subjected to the western male gaze, dollification, and being considered exotic and submissive for their masculine fans in a patriarchal society.<ref name=":9" /> Femininity is desired to coincide with the neo-Confucian patriarchal social structure so as to maximize profit; idols are normally forced into this definition in conjunction with Korea's inherently well-defined roll for women.<ref name=":9" /> Additionally, being below Japan's Global Gender Gap Index and aligned with Muslim-majority countries’, South Korea's Global Gender Gap Index represents the general poor state of gender equality in South Korea.<ref name=":9" /> Xi Lin and Rober Rudolf conducted a survey of 6,317 K-pop fans from 100 countries to determine the egalitarianism of the K-pop consumers.<ref name=":9" /> Their study found that more K-pop indulgence correlated to less egalitarianism, with this being most notable in already gender stratified countries.<ref name=":9" /> Similarly, the stratification of genders in Korea is actually aided by the government and its patriarchal capitalism, and vice-versa.<ref name=":9" /> That is, sexism and sexualization in K-pop support the success of South Korea's patriarchal capitalism, forcing norms of gender inequalities and the sexual objectification of female K-pop idols.<ref name=":9" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Sexualization]] [[Category:K-pop]]

revision.text:
The '''TenTen Corpus Family''' (also called '''TenTen corpora''') is a set of comparable web [[text corpora]], i.e. collections of texts that have been [[Web crawler|crawled]] from the [[World Wide Web]] and processed to match the same standards. These corpora are made available through the [[Sketch Engine]] corpus manager. There are TenTen corpora for more than 35 languages. Their target size is 10 billion (10<sup>10</sup>) words per language, which gave rise to the corpus family's name.<ref name="tenten">{{cite conference|last1=Jakubíček|first1=Miloš|last2=Kilgarriff|first2=Adam|author-link2=Adam Kilgarriff|last3=Kovář|first3=Vojtěch|last4=Rychlý|first4=Pavel|last5=Suchomel|first5=Vít|date=July 2013|title=The Tenten Corpus Family|url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/The_TenTen_Corpus_2013.pdf|conference=7th International Corpus Linguistics Conference CL|location=Lancaster, UK|publisher=Lancaster University|pages=125–127|access-date=13 June 2017|book-title=}}</ref>
In the creation of the TenTen corpora, data crawled from the World Wide Web are processed with [[natural language processing]] tools developed by the Natural Language Processing Centre at the Faculty of Informatics at [[Masaryk University]] ([[Brno]], [[Czech Republic]]) and by the Lexical Computing company (developer of the Sketch Engine).
== Corpus linguistics ==
In [[corpus linguistics]], a [[text corpus]] is a large and structured collection of texts that are electronically stored and processed. It is used to do hypothesis testing about languages, validating linguistic rules or the frequency distribution of words ([[n-grams]]) within languages.
Electronically processed corpora provide fast search. Text processing procedures such as [[Lexical_analysis#Tokenization|tokenization]], [[part-of-speech tagging]] and [[word-sense disambiguation]] enrich corpus texts with detailed linguistic information. This enables to narrow the search to a particular [[Part of speech|parts of speech]], word sequences or a specific part of the corpus.
First text corpora were created in the 1960s, such as the 1-million-word [[Brown Corpus]] of [[American English]]. Over time, many further corpora were produced (such as the [[British National Corpus]] and the [[Lancaster-Oslo-Bergen Corpus|LOB Corpus]]) and work had begun also on corpora of larger sizes and covering other languages than English. This development was linked with the emergence of corpus creation tools that help achieve larger size, wider coverage, cleaner data etc.
== Production of TenTen corpora == The procedure by which TenTen corpora are produced is based on the creators' earlier research in preparing web corpora and the subsequent processing thereof.<ref>{{cite conference|last1=Baroni|first1=Marco|last2=Kilgarriff|first2=Adam|author-link2=Adam Kilgarriff|last3=Kovář|first3=Vojtěch|last4=Rychlý|first4=Pavel|last5=Suchomel|first5=Vít|date=July 2013|title=Large linguistically-processed web corpora for multiple languages|url=http://clic.cimec.unitn.it/marco/publications/eacl2006/dewac_eacl.pdf|conference=11th Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Posters & Demonstrations. Association for Computational Linguistics|location=Trento, Italy|publisher=Lancaster University|pages=87–90|access-date=13 June 2017|book-title=}}</ref><ref>{{cite conference|last1=Kilgarriff|first1=Adam|last2=Reddy|first2=Siva|last3=Pomikálek|first3=Jan|last4=Avinesh|first4=PVS|date=May 2010|title=A Corpus Factory for Many Languages|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_url?url=http://web2py.iiit.ac.in/research_centres/publications/download/inproceedings.pdf.b181796127d016be.37395f50617065722e706466.pdf&hl=cs&sa=T&oi=gsb-ggp&ct=res&cd=0&ei=-NI_WYC3LtDa2Aac7JbwDg&scisig=AAGBfm3FZuUgV9k-HjJI7B9I4v1PXmYsJA|conference=7th Language Resources and Evaluation Conference|location=Valletta, Malta|publisher=ELRA|pages=|access-date=13 June 2017|author-link1=Adam Kilgarriff|book-title=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|chapter-url=http://wackybook.sslmit.unibo.it/pdfs/sharoff.pdf|title=Wacky! Working papers on the Web as Corpus|last1=Sharoff|first1=Serge|date=2006|publisher=GEDIT|isbn=978-88-6027-004-7|editor-last1=Baroni|editor-first1=Marco|location=Bologna, Italy|pages=63–98|chapter=Creating general-purpose corpora using automated search engine queries|editor-last2=Bernardini|editor-first2=Silvia}}</ref>
At the beginning, a huge amount of text data is [[Web crawler|downloaded]] from the World Wide Web by the dedicated SpiderLing web crawler.<ref name="crawling">{{cite conference |title=Efficient web crawling for large text corpora |last1= Suchomel|first1= Vít|last2= Pomikálek|first2= Jan|date=17 April 2012|publisher= Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) on Web as Corpus |book-title= Proceedings of the seventh Web as Corpus Workshop (WAC7)|pages=39–43 |location= Lyon, France |conference= 7th Web as Corpus Workshop|url=https://nlp.fi.muni.cz/~xsuchom2/papers/PomikalekSuchomel_SpiderlingEfficiency.pdf |access-date=13 June 2017}}</ref> In a later stage, these texts undergo [[Data cleansing|cleaning]], which consists of removing any non-textual material such as navigation links, headers and footers from the [[HTML]] source code of web pages with the jusText tool<ref name="justext">{{cite thesis |last=Pomikálek |first=Jan |date=2011 |title=Removing boilerplate and duplicate content from web corpora |type=PhD |chapter= |publisher=Faculty of Informatics, Masaryk University |docket= |oclc= |url=http://theses.cz/id/nqo9nn/?furl=%2Fid%2Fnqo9nn%2F;lang=en |access-date=17 April 2017}}</ref>, so that only full solid sentences are preserved. Eventually, the ONION tool<ref name="justext" /> is applied to [[Data deduplication|remove duplicate text portions]] from the corpus, which naturally occur on the World Wide Web due to practices such as [[quotation|quoting]], [[citation|citing]], [[copying]] etc.<ref name="tenten" />
== TenTen corpora data structure == TenTen corpora follow a specific metadata structure that is common to all of them. Metadata is contained in structural attributes that relate to individual documents and paragraphs in the corpus. Some TenTen corpora can feature additional specific attributes.
=== Document attributes ===
*[[top-level domain]] – domain at the highest level of the hierarchical [[Domain Name System]] (e.g. "com") *[[website]] – identification string defining a realm of administrative autonomy within the Internet (e.g. "wikipedia.org") *[[Domain name|web domain]] – collection of related web pages (e.g. "la.wikipedia.org") *crawl date – date when the document was downloaded from the Web *url – the [[Uniform Resource Locator]] referring to the document's source *wordcount – number of words in the document *length – classification of the document into a range by its length measured in thousands of words
=== Paragraph attributes ===
*[[Headline|heading]] – a numeric attribute distinguishing [[Page header|headers]] and similar titles from ordinary [[body text]] (1 if the paragraph is a heading, 0 otherwise)
== Available TenTen corpora == The following corpora can be accessed through the Sketch Engine as of October 2018:<ref>{{cite web |title=TenTen Corpus Family |url=https://www.sketchengine.eu/documentation/tenten-corpora/ |website=www.sketchengine.eu |publisher=Sketch Engine |accessdate=23 October 2018}}</ref> {{columns-list| #arTenTen ([[Arabic]] web corpus)<ref>Belinkov, Y., Habash, N., Kilgarriff, A., Ordan, N., Roth, R., & Suchomel, V. (2013). [https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/arTenTen_corpus_for_Arabic_2013.pdf arTen-Ten: a new, vast corpus for Arabic]. ''Proceedings of WACL''.</ref> #beTenTen ([[Belarusian language|Belarusian]] web corpus)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sketchengine.eu/new-belarusian-corpus/ |title=A new Belarusian corpus (beTenTen) |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2018-02-26 |website=[[Sketch Engine]] |publisher=Lexical Computing |access-date=2018-04-06 |quote=}}</ref> #bgTenTen ([[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]] web corpus)<ref>Kilgarriff, A., Jakubíček, M., Pomikalek, J., Sardinha, T. B., & Whitelock, P. (2014). [http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/working-with-portuguese-corpora-9781441190505/ PtTenTen: a corpus for Portuguese lexicography]. ''Working with Portuguese Corpora'', 111-30.</ref> #caTenTen ([[Catalan language|Catalan]] web corpus) #csTenTen ([[Czech language|Czech]] web corpus)<ref>{{Cite conference|last=Suchomel|first=Vít|date=December 7–9, 2012|title=Recent Czech Web Corpora|url=http://raslan2012.nlp-consulting.net/|book-title=Proceedings of Recent Advances in Slavonic Natural Language Processing, RASLAN 2012|publisher=Tribun EU|editor-last=Horák|editor-first=A.|editor-last2=Rychlý|editor-first2=P.|pages=77–83}}</ref> #daTenTen ([[Danish language|Danish]] web corpus) #deTenTen ([[German language|German]] web corpus) #elTenTen ([[Greek language|Greek]] web corpus) #enTenTen ([[English language|English]] web corpus)<ref>Kilgarriff, A. (2012, September). [https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-32790-2_1 Getting to know your corpus]. In ''International Conference on Text, Speech and Dialogue'' (pp. 3-15). Springer Berlin Heidelberg.</ref> #esTenTen ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] web corpus with [[Peninsular Spanish|European]]/[[Spanish language in the Americas|American Spanish]] subcorpora)<ref>Kilgarriff, A., & Renau, I. (2013). [https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/esTenTen_web_corpus_of_Peninsular_and_American_Spanish_2013.pdf esTenTen, a vast web corpus of Peninsular and American Spanish]. ''Procedia-Social and Behavioral Sciences'', 95, 12-19.</ref> #etTenTen ([[Estonian language|Estonian]] web corpus)<ref>SRDANOVIĆ, I. (2016). [http://www.ninjal.ac.jp/event/specialists/project-meeting/files/JCLWorkshop_no3_papers/JCLWorkshop_No3_29.pdf A Research Project on Language Resources for Learners of Japanese]. ''Inter Faculty'', 6.</ref> #fiTenTen ([[Finnish language|Finnish]] web corpus) #frTenTen ([[French language|French]] web corpus) #heTenTen ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] web corpus) #hiTenTen ([[Hindi]] web corpus) #huTenTen ([[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] web corpus) #itTenTen ([[Italian language|Italian]] web corpus) #jaTenTen ([[Japanese language|Japanese]] web corpus) #kmTenTen ([[Khmer language|Khmer]] web corpus) #koTenTen ([[Korean language|Korean]] web corpus) #loTenTen ([[Lao language|Lao]] & [[Isan language|Isan]] web corpus) #ltTenTen ([[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] web corpus) #lvTenTen ([[Latvian language|Latvian]] web corpus) #mkTenTen ([[Macedonian language|Macedonian]] web corpus) #nlTenTen ([[Dutch language|Dutch]] web corpus) #noTenTen ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] web corpus) #plTenTen ([[Polish language|Polish]] web corpus) #ptTenTen ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] web corpus) #roTenTen ([[Romanian language|Romanian]] web corpus) #ruTenTen ([[Russian language|Russian]] web corpus) #skTenTen ([[Slovak language|Slovak]] web corpus) #slTenTen ([[Slovene language|Slovenian]] web corpus) #svTenTen ([[Swedish language|Swedish]] web corpus) #thTenTen ([[Thai language|Thai]] web corpus) #tlTenTen ([[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] web corpus) #trTenTen ([[Turkish language|Turkish]] web corpus)<ref>{{Cite conference|last=Baisa|first=Vít|last2=Suchomel|first2=Vít|date=2015|title=Turkic Language Support in Sketch Engine|url=https://is.muni.cz/publication/1311893/cs?lang=en|book-title=Proceedings of the international conference "Turkic Languages processing: TurkLang 2015"|publisher=Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Tatarstan Press|publication-place=Kazan|volume=|pages=214–223|isbn=978-5-9690-0262-3|via=IS MU}}</ref> #ukTenTen ([[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] web corpus) #zhTenTen ([[Simplified Chinese characters|Chinese Simplified characters]] web corpus) }}
== See also == * [[Text corpus]] * [[Sketch Engine]] * [[Web crawler]] (spider) * [[Data deduplication]]
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/documentation/tenten-corpora/ TenTen Corpus Family] (at the Sketch Engine website)
